Long wait but a local guy finally stopped. Told me about how he didn't look both ways at the traintrack once last year and his truck got hit and everything was destroyed except for him. Said he used to drive 100 mph all the way to Chicago to go see his girlfriend back in the 70s.

Long wait but a local guy finally stopped. Told me about how he didn't look both ways at the traintrack once last year and his truck got hit and everything was destroyed except for him. Said he used to drive 100 mph all the way to Chicago to go see his girlfriend back in the 70s.
~20 minutes to El Granada the spot has enough space for people to turn off, cars are moving fast and many cars but good spot overall
idk why is everyone tryied to find a ride way up, Where i stayed it much closer to traffic light so traffic is slow there and people see you better
Took five minutes on a Friday during ski season. Took five hours on a Saturday in June.

Great for getting "down the hill."  You don't even need a sign; just stick out your thumb and wait ... however waiting time could be up to 1 hour.  Don't look like a bum here.  A sign that says "LA" might help.
I often hitch from here to SLC. 10-15 minute wait time, friendly cool students

Although technically 'illegal' in Utah, HHing from Cache Valley to Salt Lake City is super easy.  Just make sure you keep walking so you don't break the law!  I've had mormon families pick me up, couples, and the sad lonely old man.
gas / sevice  station  6  km North of  Orel , reached  by  marshrutka  to  Mtsensk
На Брянск. Выезд из Орла автобусом от автовокзала.
for us it was hard because of the heavy traffic and people driving on the shoulder lane. got a ride in 30 min to a better spot
This spot is rather simple to hitch from. I wasn't even facing the traffic when 2 cars stopped at the same time.

Moab is the absolutel best for hitchin'!!!! Loads of friendly adventurers around the area, tourists, free camping all over the place (incl along the river!), locals are cool too, walking 191 in any direction is a great walk along with great views, before some friendly person picks you up. and if you&they cool perhaps you'll get picked up on some sweet adventure! ;o) it's an amazing place, a good one to take out of the box. BIGlove
I needed a ride to the Arches National Park (north). Had to wait half an hour. Find a shade.

Got a ride to Gainesville on a Sunday around 1:30pm. Waited about 15 minutes, and got a trucker. Not a ton of traffic at that time.

(female, 20s)

Headed south on a Sunday around 11:30, waited with a sign for I-75 S. Got a ride in about 10 minutes. Great location.

(female, 20s)

Going South from Syracuse is difficult. The on-ramp before this one is in a bad neighbourhood which keeps cars from stopping, the one before that has no place to stop. 
This one worked quick for me. Take the green bus "Sy 10" until the last station which is "S. Salina & E. Conklin Ave" I think and then walk one mile to the South.
Great spot! Cars are very slow and have a lane where they can stop. Doesn't get better than this.
Good place to get a lift south on 95.  Stay close enough to the turn that people are still going slow, but far enough that they get a good look at you!

Headed towards Chicago. Waited 10 minutes, then took a ride to Beloit (a lot of short distance traffic here), which I recommend. Held a sign for "Illinois" at 3pm on a Thursday.

(female, 20s)

Headed to Chicago, got a ride to Black River Falls within 10 minutes. Thumbing at 10am on a Thursday.

(female, 20s)
Nice on-ramp. Could imagine some folks not wanting to pull over here. My ride stopped in the middle of the road! 13 min wait

Headed East, held a sign for Eau Claire and got a ride in about 10 minutes. 

(female, 20s)

Headed East, held a sign for Eau Claire and got a ride within 10 minutes. Not a ton of traffic at noon on a Tuesday, but seems okay.  

(female, 20s)
Didn't feel good about being dropped here. The on-ramp out of Scotia worked, though. 30 mins--got a ride all the way to the Oakland.
Waited 45 mins for a ride...from a fucking cop! Erik Estrada drove me 4 mi from the freeway. My day was just not the same after that.

Not bad actually! I was on my way to the the reggae festival and had a sign that said "REGGAE", and got picked up before I'd even found a hitching spot. People around here seem pretty cool. (with the exception of the meth-heads!)

Headed North, got a ride to Anoka. Used a sign reading 'North'. About a 15 minute wait on a Saturday at 2pm.

(female, 20s)

Headed to Minneapolis, got a semi to Lakeville. 11am on a Saturday. Sign reading 'North'

(female, 20s)

Headed East. Pretty poor traffic at 9am on a Sunday. Still, had an offer and a ride as far as I-35 within two minutes.

(female, 20s)
Somewhere close to here. Dropped at a trailer park at the edge of town. Big-ass boat converted to a gift shop. 23 min wait to Crescent City.

Waited less than an hour for a ride west!  When I got in the car I told the guy that it would be nice to get into IN today, even though his destination was still in MI, and he said that he would take me across the border!  We were headed for Gary, IN when he offered to buy me a bus ticket farther west!!  Super great guy and super generous.  Decent amount of traffic, should be able to catch a ride!!

Waited about a half an hour when an old couple picked me up and drove me to Watervliet, MI.  They were super nice, even gave me a cookie!  But they were super religious and had me pray with them before I got out of their car.

Headed east, got a ride all the way to Bozeman within 15 minutes. 11am on a Saturday morning. Thumbin'!

(female, 20s)
Good place to get a lift to New Jersey.
Not a bad place to hitch out of the town, was able to get a ride easily towards lee vining from here. Good shoulders and traffic
Outside the plaza there is a pretty good stretch for cars to see you and pull over. Didn't take longer than 15 minutes to get a ride south and towards Sacramento
I spent a total of six minutes hitchiung from exit 5 on I-27. I caught a ride all the way to Amarillo.
Been droped off by the city center from lloleta so i had to walk up her a good spot that took me to Grand's pass !
Under the bridge at the shade wass going north , been pick up after 1h and 20 min , 2 cars already stop before very quickly but they where going nearby ! So ill say not bad at all even average
good place
There is an OK spot in at the entrance of the Julia Pfeiffer Ranger Station (and parking). I waited 20 minutes for a short ride early morning at 7AM.
Shitty spot to hitch but the second car that came up on this dead ass spot took us all the way to golden.
Better than the first exit if you're coming from the south. People actually go slow here.
Always a good spot to hitch north, just takes a bit, usually.
Cops here are friendly, would't let me hitch while they were coordinating a mega-haul, though. Wait time 1.5 hours.
Pretty slow, waited an hour, so pretty good considering. Stop sign across the street means people have a chance to consider picking you up. Got a ride all the way to San Antonio by a rich oil dude!

Lovely lot lizard at the truck stopp, who berated me for not wanting to use her small crumpled up piece of cardboard. Another guy showed up at the same on-ramp, going off the same info from this site. We talked, he started walking, because it was MY on ramp, and instantly we both got a ride.

Love's truck stop near exit. Best place to hitchhike south from Phoenix area-- to Tucson or further on I-20 East. Large on-ramp. Hitchhiked here two times. I recommend to wait for a ride at least to I-8 junction (many truck stops) or Tucson.
'bout an hour and a half wait. Nice  people, great kickdowns.

Big truck stop with nice employees that didn't mind me asking around. Apparently only a very small number of vehicles use this ramp, but I still got a ride to my destination in Kentucky from a trucker that was going all the way to Chicago.

Got a ride a few miles east after 30 mins. People mostly drive locally here, so get ready for town-hopping hitchhiking. Little by little I finally made it further east without ever waiting longer than 1 hour, and got a long ride to Tennessee then.

Very big truck stop, but truckers just aren't allowed to take passengers. The place is damn busy, but I had to wait an hour to get a few miles down the road to another truck stop in the desert.  Police drove by and didn't do anything, maybe because I didn't have a sign.
Pretty busy entrance, at least in the central hours of the day. People tend to drive not very far here, but still useful!
Pretty busy, I got a ride directly to Sacramento! :D
Pilot Travel Center. Possible to get a ride here going south. Didn't get harassed. Took me a few days, but got a ride straight through to Amarillo, TX. Also has a place to camp secluded from view.
pretty good spot to get picked up, didn't take too long
Good place to get a lift from if your dropped of here, but there are no facilities. Took less than 10 minutes. Also a very beautiful place.
not a lot of traffic but a very nice friendly lady deputy sheriff gave me a lift to cheyenne :). last exit with services til' wyoming

This place is not very busy, but there's a big Pilot truck stop right off the highway. Awesomely, I got picked up by a truck headed to Reno, NV, that took me straight to Albuquerque, NM. 
Besides, the truck stop is surrounded by nice woods to camp in. The truck stop staff is actually pretty helpful. A guy that works there told me it was no problem to camp in the nearby woods, and wished me good luck with getting a ride the next day.
Pretty busy gas station. I asked drivers and got a ride after 40 mins :)
Big road with wide shoulder and heave traffic. Just be patient and someone will stop for sure!
Not many cars, but still good to reach Kentucky quickly.
Got a ride south almost immediately from the little settled area here.
Got a ride here from an employee at the brewery. Nothing else really here, but people there will be cool to you. Got a ride to Santa Cruz in half an hour.
Not a ton of southbound traffic, but I got a ride in no time.
Not a lot here, but good visibility, and the traffic is thin but steady. Got a ride in under an hour. Nifty gem/mineral shop/museum right here.
Quickly got a good ride to around Fort Dick with an evangelistic police officer.
Got a ride pretty quickly to Butte.
Got a ride pretty quickly out of the park in the late evening. Really chill elk hang out right here. It's just a thing, I guess.
The one gas station here will give you a free meal if you're just passing through, and a little goodie bag to help you out down the road.
Lots of small town ride offers, but that's literally most of the traffic on this highway; local.

For Savannah and points south. Stood at the exit of the Shell gas station and waited less than half an hour. There is a stop light so cars have slowed down and have a place to pull into and you can also get traffic leaving the gas station. Many cars are going to Savannah.
1.5 hours for ride offer to Souix Falls. Not bad considering it's southern MN and Heading into SD
The people here are extremely nice to travelers, Within 20 minutes of being there I had a pocket full of cash and even with my beard, it only took 2 hours for a ride up to Minneapolis,
Didn't take long to get a ride up to Ellsworth,
Bus stop. Good to going into Sun Valley direction and further to East. However traffic is mostly local and heading mostly Sun Valley it is possible to get further, especially to the mountains.
I was waiting at the entrance of the Big Sur Ranger Station for an hour. It was pretty early, 8AM. I wanted to go to Santa Cruz. After 1 hour I got a ride to Monterey at least.

Southbound. Just after the village there is a spot for cars to pull over. You can also try at the village, but there you might miss out on a few cars departing. I was offered 4 rides in 45 min. Got a ride to Santa Barbara and two beers :) Hwy 1 hitchhiking is great!
Road construction here, got dropped off and found that there was no shoulder... still managed to get a ride though :)
used to live north of palmer. usually really easy and quick rides in and out of town. we would go just to grab a case of beer or some groceries and total trip would be a couple hours or so.
Stood on the on ramp going east for 2 hours until someone stopped, my sign simply said I-90 East. He took me all the way to livingston.
Got a ride fairly quickly from a trucker who brought me out to a small town with no traffic.
got a few ride offers, even someone who bought me food. not a lot of traffic but it only was 45 mins before I got a ride 20 mins into the middle of nowhere northbound.
Lots of rides going to IA. got one right away.
Traffic going all directions from the TA and Loves truck stops.
45 mins wait with 2 people.
I26 onramp with a lot of grass and good visibility; shoulder is pretty tight though.

Most are willing to drive short distances. Enough traffic to wait for better hitch, though. (don't get stuck in Wallace.) Really nice area to bed down for the night under bridge. water crystal clear but may have lead and arsenic.
Not the busiest exit, but people were friendly, got kicked down a few bucks and dog food before after only 45 minutes of waiting on on ramp got ride to Columbus.
Even just sitting making a sign I had 4 people come up to me offering money or food. Within 2 minutes of putting up a sign for Fargo I got a ride all the way to Billings, MT
Good place to get a ride onto I-76 E (towards center city, New Jersey)
Great place to get a lift on I-76 W.
For I-95 S.
A good place to get a lift on I-76 from center city.  Traffic can go east or west on 76 so use a sign or ask the driver.

had 2 people stop within a minute of sticking my thumb out. nice fellow named steve, live in the next town i was headed to, berea. people from all over using this on ramp so good chance for a long distance

Silver Eagle gas station is your best bet, if you are travelling eastbound. Friendly staff, free wifi, cheapest gas in town, and lots of long distance riders stopping to refresh. We have been waiting here for 4 hours as we want a ride at least to Grand Junction, but waiting here is not bad at all. reporting right from the spot.
Got ride to Eau Claire within 30 minutes. Probably would have been less of a wait if I was on I-94
Found a ride with someone going jade hunting who bought me lunch and loaded me up with water! Stop at the park here if you can, well worth it
Right outside the entrance to Big Sur Camp Ground. People on the CA 1 are awesome, took me less than 15 minutes.
Nice little spot, surprisingly. Go for it :)
Westbound on-ramp at exit 7

There's an AM PM here with a dumpster full of cardboard.  I got a huge piece and wrote "PHX or LA - I don't stink."  .... the word "much" was written in tiny letters ;)

got a lift in 5 minutes.

The on-ramp is not bad, and there's a big fuel station with tons of truckers you can talk to. There's a sign saying hitchhikers/pedestrians aren't allowed on the interstate, but there's enough space to stand well ahead of the sign.

If you're heading southbound, you can find truckers here going really long distances.  The guy who picked me up was on his way to Pennsylvania. Even if you're going north, someone might drive you to the border and have you walk over.

I wanted to go through the Holland Tunnel, took about 10 minutes.
Easy, trafficlights
Got a ride with people going to Valdez within half an hour wait. There wasn't a lot of people though there in September.
Hitching west to the Richardson Highway. Ask people coming back on the foot bridge, everyone going back has to pass there.

In September (after the tourist season) waited half an hour to get a ride to Kenny Lake. After that it was much harder for me. 3 hours waiting to get a ride to McCarthy. But earlier with all the tourists you may get lucky.

Going east to McCarthy-Kennicott. Easy to hitch a ride as far as Kenny Lake or Chitina. Then it gets tricky.

Cars slow after the turn, good place to pull over.
After 5 minutes a guy going to Eagle River stopped, I didn't go with him, then after another 10 minutes got a ride to Palmer. Great spot!

Hitching north to Palmer, Denali, Fairbanks.

Great spot. Stood near Muldoon Road just before the an on-ramp and no pedestrians signs. There's a lot of cars turning to the freeway, going to Palmer, they are slow since just have passed traffic lights, and there is some place to pull over.
To get a ride back to Fairbanks, just ask around. Didn't have much problem with that and a tourist that stayed at Deadhorse Camp agreed to take me.
After 15 minutes got a ride to Hilltop Truck Stop.

Hitching north to Prudhoe Bay!

The traffic from here on gets scarce, but there are some cars and people are friendly. Spot has everything it needs to have. Oh, and there's a weigh station nearby - it was empty at the time I was there, but maybe you get a chance to ask for a ride there.
Going South, we got a ride to Birmingham after 1h i guess on a tuesday around 6pm, a couple with big backpacks. Good visibility and space to pull over, police didn't bother us :)
Quite good place to hitch a ride. Wide shoulder on the ramp to I-80 west.
Great spot to hitchhike. I drunk coffee in nearby DD and then went to that spot and waited for 5 minutes.

I have started 2 hitchhiking trips west from this same location. About 5 - 10 cars a minute, going generally slow, with enough room to pull over while other cars can still get by. Only took about 30-45 minutes each time. Public transportation from NYC: I got dropped off here, but there is also a NJ transit bus stop exactly 1 mile away (W. Main St. & Wall St., Rockaway) which you can bus to from Morristown, and you can get to Morristown from NYC via NY Penn Station. A bit of a stretch, but you ca
Trusty spot for those northbound, last chance in town so you get all the traffic, rides range from Saint George to Salt Lake City many times.
A great place to get truck rides across the country.  Lots of truck traffic and the staff won't kick you out.  But be prepared to wait a few hours, as is usual in the USA.
Good place to hitchhike north.
Good for hitchhiking north west to Boulder City or south west to LA. Took just over an hour of waiting. Got a lift to the Hover Dam.

Fairly good place to hitchhike to the Grand Canyon. There's places to pull over and cars going beyond this point are likely to be going to the grand Canyon. It's quite far out of Flagstaff. There's a bus that takes you half the way then it's about a 2 hour walk to this spot.
Good place to hitchhike west. Lots of car use this route and there is plenty of room for cars to pull over.
Good place to hitchhike west, plenty of cars passing with room to pull over. Waited two hours for a ride.
Good place to catch rides south west. Might have to wait around a while though.
Got a ride to Half Moon Bay in the morning after just 10min
Hitching from SF to Santa Cruz, took the 110 here and got picked up within 20 minutes
Super windy but nice truckers. I flew a sign to Salt Lake City and a trucker approached me before going into the gas station.
Just a stop light and the intersection to Big Sky. Hold a sign and look happy :)
Not a ton of traffic. A gas station right across the street where lots of truckers stop, though.
Plenty of space to relax. Took about an hour for a ride.
Not a huge shoulder, but a decent flow of traffic. Took about an hour to get a ride.
The infamous, "Stampede Road/Trail," from "Into the Wild."  Good spot; signs work great, too.  Morning is always easier than afternoon/night.

Tons of cars coming and going; it's best to hitch before noon.  Having a sign is a good idea but not necessary.  DON'T GET DISCOURAGED!  Lots of people are just going 10 miles and they don't realize that even 10 miles helps.  I've used a sign that's said, "14 Miles," and it's worked wonders!

HAVE A SIGN if you're hitching long distance here.  If you're here in the summer (I pity you if you're hitching here in the winter), there are FREE SHUTTLE buses from the Denali National Park area to here (look up the "McKinley Village Lodge), so you can get out of tourist hell and back on the road southbound.  This is great because it's out of the park, and just before a steep hill climb, which makes drivers drive slower than normal.
A better detour if you're stuck in Victorville.  Do NOT look like a bum here, there are too many old beggars around already.  This road will take you to a giant truck stop in Barstow.
Brilliant spot to spend a night and a beautiful place to hitch. The bridge had a shoulder fifteen feet wide, waited maybe 45 minutes but it was early morning and not many cars.

Waited maybe 20 minutes, denser part of the coast, less space, take the bus to cross Lincoln City rather than walking,  costs a dollar and saves 10 miles walking or trying to hitch through the strip malls.
Cars have to slow down for bend and there's a decent shoulder, not ideal but works. Waited maybe 20 minutes.
Friendly town, not a lot of traffic, lifted only a mile to Nehalem. Waited maybe 15 minutes.
Waited about 15 minutes for a short ride to the next town
People are super friendly, ugly area, strip mall and all that, picked up by just the right type of farmer after about 15 minutes
Waited about 20 minutes, picked up by a guy, new in town, took us onto the wrong freeway
Got a ride northbound for two in about thirty minutes, seems like a good spot
Going north. I've dropped someone off and hitched this spot myself. The guy I dropped off found a ride before I could even turn around and it took me 5 minutes before someone stopped.
this is a good place to stand to get out of farmington if you're heading for western maine.
Good spot for heading north to the flathead. Not a lot of traffic but everyone is going far. Beautiful country aswell.
In front of Hospital. Got a ride to wailua. 20 minutes wait.
I-70 West: Cars have to turn 90 degrees so don't stay right by the corner. There's room to pull over and the waiting time shouldn't be too long. I waited for half an hour.
easy rides on the rockies
Good spot for westbound traffic. 2 gas stations, 7eleven. Cars come around the corner slowly, plenty of room to pull over. Other side looks a bit more difficult but should be doable.
I say there is enough room for cars to pull off, there's a tree on the ramp so you won't get too hot. I had to wait three hours. Once you're on the rockies, it's easier to get rides.

To the I-70 West. Take bus 16Ltd from anywhere on Colfax. You can catch traffic coming from Denver as well as Golden. Not much room for cars to pull over though. 50 feet east is stop light, also possible to ask cars there as they stop, best with sign. Waited 1 hour, ride to Eagle for two.
With a sign for "CANADA", plenty of friendly cars stopped, though most were only going as far as Kingston.  After under an hour got a ride to just south of Albany.
Lots of traffic here, as likely to stop as anywhere else in the city.  Got a ride to Tarrytown in about an hour.
Lots of traffic at rushours people commute over the pass.
A lot of traffic going West, I waited about an hour and got a ride passed Sioux Falls. Make a sign- which cardboard can be found at the grocery store down the street.

Going to Sumas to cross the border, picked up in 10 minutes and dropped there, crossing the border walking.
Guy alone with a big backpack on a tuesday, around 1pm.
Going East to Willis, we got picked up within 1 hour i guess. 2 guys with big bagpacks. Good spot with a wide shoulder in front of an hotel.

Lake Ozette Rd. Fairly easy to hike out here and get a ride back to civilization. Traffic is light and you have a much better chance on the weekend. Hike past a couple of driveways rather then stand at the ranger station.
Most folks from here are going long distances.  After bad luck in Pensecola, I got a ride here going all the way through the panhandle.  Lots of traffic and good wide shoulders, good for hitching.

I had an easy time hitching along I-10 through LA, but was hassled by the cops on more than one occasion.  They all thought it was illegal, but there is a loophole in their law which allows standing on the shoulder for solicitation, just not in the actual roadway.  Know your rights, and they can't do anything.  The rides came quick, I made it nearly to New Orleans in one day.
Got a ride from here over to Clinton, MO about 15 minutes after starting.
Started my journey here and was picked up within ten minutes.
There is some kind of pull-in rest stop around here that is just bathrooms and maybe vending machines. Found a ride very quickly
Very good place, lots of people stopped. Not many of them were going as far north as we wanted. It took a while to get a ride to Longview.
This is an okay spot heading north to olympia & seattle. You can take an express c-tran bus from downtown portland here; take it to the end - "salmon creek park & ride".
there is a parking lot next to the road for cars to pull into.  should be enough yosemite-bound traffic to get rides.
Dude picked me up as it was getting dark, heading south toward Petoskey.  had a funny conversation, then Dude lets me crash at his house.
Southbound. A good spot, but one that can get competitive when lots of travelers are in town.

Outside the Grand Canyon National Airport. Great spot to get back to Flagstaff or Phoenix. If you're heading to Phoenix, you may want to fly a sign. I've hitched a dozen times from this spot, and never had to wait more than 40 minutes to get a ride.
Good for hitching to Yuma, San Diego, and LA. Directly on the I-8. Just watch for border patrol.
hiking east.
Citgo
On ramp. Plenty of space to stop. No gas station nearby, though.

Going north. There's a traffic light that changes lights frequently enough for people to stop and see you. There's also a right turn lane for people coming out of Cambria. As with most cases on the CA 1, people are awesome. I found some Swiss to take me all the way to Big Sur.
CA 1 Northbound. This place has good traffic albeit many are not the type to pick up hitchers. I stood right next to the sign and took no longer than 20 minutes.
There's a gas station right on the side. I seemed to get lucky and find a ride pretty quickly.

If coming back to Portland from Eagle Creek, you'll either be looking for a lift in the parking lot, or you'll have to hop across four lanes of high-speed motorway and the U.P. tracks to get over to the westbound hitching spot, as there's no westbound onramp. This spot is fairly nice as there's a long straightaway for cars to see you and a very wide shoulder for pulling off. Also, hitching on interstates in Oregon is not illegal - though walking across traffic probably is.
One of the better spots to hitchhike south in Eugene. Rides are usually headed to Creswell or Cottage Grove.
Somewhat poor spot in Sutherlin. Walk two miles up to exit 138, it's much better.
This seems like an awesome spot to get as far north as Eugene or Salem.
Good for hitching to Kingman, LA, or Vegas.
Fairly high speeds, but good visibility
Slightly east of this mark is a good way to get to the I-5 via the 38, plus the local bakery sells a bag of day old donuts for $3.
Across the bridge here going northbound got me a ride within 30 minutes, though this seems like it could be variable as most of the traffic was summer tourists.
Right across from a truck stop.  Not very high traffic, but nonetheless got a ride north to Bangor within about 5 minutes.

heading north out of springs. very easy.

entire length of 25 in CO is easy.

high traffic but mostly local. large truck stops on both sides. better luck with truckers, cars are all locals.
ramp wasnt working so i hopped on the road. got picked up 5 minutes after that during morning rush hour. this is the last stop before it turns to concrete barriers for a while
good spot. lots of traffic. fairly large town with good stores. semi decent truck stops.
decent spot. friendly people. took a while. was going up to 80. got one ride all the way. lots of people go to 80 on this road.

Nice spot for going North or South on I-5, or West on Highway 12.

This place is real finicky! Make sure you LOOK and ACT your BEST!  There's tons of competition; including meth mouths asking for spare change (spangers) for "beer," old school dead heads vying for gas money and other hitchhikers going all directions.

At the Flying J, you can ask people directly for a lift.  I think having a sign is a good idea, so you can walk to the trucker's area to fly it.   Mind the Flying J managers.  They
Easy to go east to Yucca, Joshua Tree and 29 Palms.  No sign needed.  Wait times vary from 3 minutes to 30 minutes.
Great spot for getting a ride.to Palmdale and beyond, however it usually takes more than one lift.  Also, remember it's still the LA area, so it might take some time to stop a car.  Be patient!
Nice spot, lots of room and a lot of traffic heading north on I-5.  Most traffic is going to Bakersfield, though, so if you're going farther up the 5 freeway, you should make a "Sacramento" sign.
Good for hitching north.

A truckstop in Olympia? This spot is probably high in the ranking for easiest spot in the States. I had a problem here with a ramp turd ( a sketchy looking man who hung out around the exit for no reason and scared away potential rides). Oh well, if this happens to you, wait em out and they'll go wander off to bum cigarettes.

Hitchhiking north out of Sacramento is a challenge, but for four dollars, one can catch a bus on J street up to this intersection in Yuba City. Stand at the corner of Hwy 20 and Hwy 99, where much of the 99's northbound traffic will have to stop or slow down at the traffic light. Plenty of room for cars or trucks to pull over. Signs may help.
Need to hold a sign otherwise I wouldn't count on a ride. It's technically still inner-suburbs.

We (2 females) were walking back to the ferry but had to pee and didn't know if we had enough time, so I stuck my thumb out while we were walking.  About 5 cars passed and one stopped in the middle of the road and took us 2.5 km to the ferry (and more importantly, the bathroom).  Cars drive slowly on Martha's Vineyard and there isn't much crime, so I don't think the people are as skeptical.
Even got a ride out to check out the Lava flow.. its wild
A few more tourists than other places but once i held out a beer someone stopped :)
Once you get back to the highway you'll be fine
As long as there is a place to slow down and stop.. they will

This experience was back in Oct. 2009 and I\\'ve heard the cops are being pricks to hitchers there now, but when I was there, I slept in the woods and in the morning around 6am under heavy fog I didn\\'t even drop my bag and the first truck passing me slammed on the breaks and drove me to Santa Rosa.
I sat on the guardrail here and caught a ride going up to almost to Port Townsend within about 20 minutes.
So people are not reluctant to pick one up? What if cops catch one?

Although illegal, hitching on this interstate wasn't so bad.  There is plenty of space for cars to stop and it doesn't seem like there were any cops or patrol cars passing by.  It took me about 15 minutes to land a ride going to Tampa.
Going north or south, nearly every car stops in Hinckley going between Duluth and the Cities.  Just get to the proper on-ramp with a sign.
Big truck stops here with many travel services. Good place to ask for ride going east or west on I-40. Entrance ramps also good for getting ride.
Easy for cars to stop. Gas station and tourist shop nearby, so many long-distance drivers stop here.
Onramp to GA-400 North towards Dahlonega.
Onramp to GA-400 towards Atlanta.

Stand on this road between two big truck stops to get a ride on I-10 east or west. (Entrance ramps along highway no good). All trucks going back to highway must pass by you. Hold a sign with your direction (I-10 West to California, for example). My average distance of rides from this place: 200 miles.

3 big truck stops here and food services. Wide on-ramp for truckers to pull over. Can get a long ride east or west from here. Also a big tree with low branches next to northbound ramp if you need to sleep.
Liberal location. Busy exit. Young drivers.
palmyra
To hitch to Thunder Bay, you can catch a bus to 2nd or 3d line and hitch along Great Northern Rd
Walk there from the border to hitch further north. You are sure to catch all traffic and not be causing/getting any problems with the authority

A lovely little gas station with a nice coffee shop next door where the eccentric pump attendant (who lives in a house across the road with a massive WORLD PEACE sign on the roof) blows giant bubbles and keeps you entertained while you wait for your ride :) Quite a nice interlude on the highway of hitchhiking hardship!

North to Olympia / Seattle. This is a suprisingly good hitching spot. Many cars stop to fill up with gas here, and since they can se you at the onramp while filling up, they have ample time to decide to pick you up when getting back on the highway. Big shoulder, too.
People often hitch east and west from these onramps
Decent spot for going South on Interstate 15.
Hitching north with a sign that said "Coos Bay."  Got a ride around 1pm within 30 minutes.

I got dropped off here by a truck driver.  Not a bad spot for going to Coos Bay, but the time of day makes a difference.  Rush hour is generally the best time, so it took me about an hour until the traffic got more dense for someone to pick me up.

Going North - sign said "FLORENCE"

Got a ride within 30 minutes.  Plenty of space on the bridge for a car to stop on the right shoulder.  Just dance on the railing while you wait.
Not a bad spot for heading south.  My sign said "BOISE."  The guy that picked me up said, "I picked you up because you're well dressed and not one of those hippies."

Hwy 95 SOUTH to BOISE

Got a lucky ride all the way to my doorstep in Boise :)
Need a ride back to Portland? Just wait here with your thumb out or ask around.
Heading to Tampa from here ... I had a sign for about an hour without luck.  About 5 minutes after I stopped using the sign, I got a lift to the I-75 onramp nearby.
Going from Rome to Birmingham, this might be the best spot.  Inside the city is a little to hectic

to HH to Harrisburg or the southern states using the I81 Interstate 81 this is a great spot to approach cars since it is a rest area. 
It is a quite frequented place so lots of people. I
was lucky and got a right after the first contact there.
albeit I waited for over and hour, I got a ride into Utah.  I had a "Utah" sign.
Got a ride to Ukiah after about 20 minutes, even though almost all traffic was going southbound.
Right in front of a campground.  Through traffic is going fairly fast but there is plenty of room for them to see you and stop.  After about an hour got a ride to Crescent City.
decent spot to get onto the I-95. also campable area.

Right before the highway turns back into freeway, so you can stand directly on the road and catch through-traffic.  Huge lay-by/shoulder to pull over into.  Waited an hour here, but when we did get a ride it took us all the way to Arcata.
Hassic Jews hitch rides at this location

Got good traffic heading North, a gas station and large shoulder. 

My driver was a rancher on his way to the library, accepted to bring me to the edge of the city. Quite silent.

Easy way to go to Helena, straight line, you can't be missed by drivers. 

A delivery man who already saw me in Bozeman earlier that day picked me up. We did one stop to deliver some axles before he dropped me in town where I asked him to.

Good spot with a good flow of cars. Not much stop at the gas station, but the place offers all kind of amenities for the wait.

After only a few minutes, almost got a ride to Bozeman, MT, but the couple changed their mind.

Finally, a young guy who moved recently in MT from CA picked me up and give me a ride in a mix of music and thoughts over life and religion.

Got a ride as I just installed myself on the pavement to panhandle and keeping an eye on the gas station.

Paige was a nurse on her way to work. She offered to host me in case I end up stuck in the area for the rest of the day.

Gas station was full when I got dropped. Time to go to the restroom and grab a lunch snack, it was empty. Panhandle on the side of the road.

A Mormon man appeared and offered me a ride. Nice, he told me a bit about the story of the area. He offered me a chocolate mint protein bar and a bottle of water.

Forgot my phone in the previous car, had to go back to Craig to pick it up. Once I secured my previous driver was aware of me coming back, I basically waved at any car going East in sense of emergency.
The second one pulled over and picked me up.

Gas station with a big parking lot. Not many cars stopping there, but lots of traffic driving between Black Hawk & the Interstate, both ways.
Straight line who allows visibility, however cars driving fast, less encline to stop.

Got a ride from a retired man from Minnesota, who is now a poker dealer. On his way back home after working for a tournament in BH, he wasn't in a hurry and drop me where he thought would be the more convenient to keep heading West.

Big shoulder, but very windy that day and no shelter.

Got a ride from a woman going home after skiing who dropped me only a few miles south as she was going through CO72. 
Offered me her hand warmers she just activated as they were useless to her now.

Walked with thumb up and a sign from Broadway&Boulder Canyon Dr intersection, as there was already someone panhandling there.

No real shoulder along the way. Someone eventually pulled out on his way to the ski resort and gave me a ride all the way there.

Was taking a snack before heading to get the bus to reach Boulder.

Start talking with my soon-to-be driver.
I looked too tired apparently, so she offered me a ride.
Had much fun with her, we hanged out in the following days and she became a friend!
wide shoulder, good people watching - a bit sketchy to get to. traffic light a bit north of pin is helpful for slowing down traffic.

Great spot, good traffic.
Cars see you from far away, place to pull over and they're forcedto slow down bc of the town. 
The general store seemed like a good place to take a rest.

Got a ride from Justin, nice old man who gave me an authentic Western vibe !
Got a ride from an old local on his way home to Holman, he offered to drop me further. He left me at the county limit in the middle of nowhere. Breathtaking scenery though.

Amazing place to stop. Little traffic as the end of the day.

I was about to give up when my driver stopped.

Former hitchhiker with his son, lots of nice stories shared.

Highly recommend NM-104 road for the scenery, breathtaking !

Got a ride from the first person I asked, a young Mexican on his way to work.

He ended up inviting me for lunch. 

We had a long conversation about how he encountered God through the Bible and became a predicator and how his life changed.

Nice gas station. Got my lunch spontaneously paid by someone in front of me in the line and people I asked a ride were very friendly.

A young man heading to Houma with his van picked me up, after first telling me it couldn't, due to a common misunderstanding. Being on a rush, he couldn't drive me all the way to the Gray exit, so he dropped me on the highway.

Lots of people stopping at Busy Bee. People working there didn't tell me anything as I was looking for a ride. 

Regarding the season, most cars were full or heading East/South, however people very friendly and even received a few bucks.

Finally got a ride from 3 Mexican men driving all the way to MS, who got convinced when I spoke to them in Spanish.

Silent ride, animated only by the Mexican radio.

Good shoulder, refused many rides because they didn't go that far.

Ended up getting a ride from a surfer/musician who was very concerned of my safety and drop me a few exits further than where he was going to improve my chances to get a next ride.

First car stopped. 

Russian immigrant with a fancy expensive car. 

Short ride, as I was going from a Marina to another one to find a boat to reach the Bahamas.

Buc-ee's, so many people to ask for a ride. Not been bothered by the station employees, probably didn't even realize I was there regarding the size of the place.
People were friendly, but mostly going North.
End up finding a guy going to Florida who accepted to do a detour to drop me where I was spending the night in exchange of some gas money.
First couple I asked picked me up after saying no first. They made room specifically for me to get inside and offered me a nice ride along the country.
Ride all the way back to Portland, great spot for going north
not a lot of traffic but good vibes. cool guy from Hot Springs let me stay the night on the way to St Regis
Long and plenty of shoulder , got a ride quick into crescent city
Ride to where the 20 and 101 intersect
Ask for rides here, lots of home bums in area , locals not rlly down for it
Asked for awhile got a ride to Tracy talking about relationship problems and driving 100 in a Corvette
Ride from Arabic guy driving 100 and eating khat
Arco not a bad place to ask, ride from a gay porn star
Asked around here and got a ride to Bakersfield
Quick ride into slabs
Caught a ride with an Armenian trucker who found me a Russian wife to El Centro
Got really lucky first person I asked dropped me a bit past Tucson
Asked around at the gas station and got a ride to El paso
Ride west for a couple hours
Walking with God , asked for a ride at the shell
Side of the highway , ride from a Turkish trucker with very little English
Asked around and got a ride fairly quick, be cautious that a lot of people in Texas carry guns though
Lots of room to stop , got a ride all the way to Beaumont
Picked up quick to Lafayette
Got a ride quick , busy area + traffic from airport
Asking around for rides here got us one to rest stop before Gainesville
Good spot to ask for rides going north or west. Got one to tampa
Ride north from grandpa and grandson hot boxing van
Big shoulder room to stop, decent amount of traffic but most of it seems to be going north, got a ride to the rest area 10 min down
Good place to ask for rides, got one to palm bay quick
Got a quick ride to the next exit where there was a truck stop

The traffic is two-laned, but there are lots of spots for drivers to pull over and you have high visibility and lots of time for people to see you
I got picked up really quickly by a very obviously high teenager. She told me that she's seen people hitchhiking here relatively often but she only picked me up since I was young. I have a feeling a lot of people here are like her lol
Ride to Columbia in the bed of a pickup
Decent amount of traffic got a quick ride into Spartanburg
Good shoulder lots of room to stop , heading east
Lots of home bums around here, someone told me locals are generally sketched about hitchhikers due to that. Short ride to Erwin
Short ride to Johnston city nice shoulder
Got a quick ride to Johnston city
Room to stop, got lucky with a ride 4 hrs south
7-11 good spot to hang and ask for rides. Locals are chill and nice
Got dropped here, waited on the shoulder of i66 got picked up pretty quick
Ride out of DC West, illegal but enough room on shoulder to stop, got picked up quick

good vis, semi dangerous if on street (fast traffic going towards 101, slower turning towards 298. decent visibility especially with sign. lots of space for cars to pullover. did not try asking at chevron gas but prob wouldnt be too bad?
Lots of cars and truckers passing through, got a ride to outside of Philly on Jersey side and took transit into town
Good spot to get back to I-5, not much use for anything long term I imagine. Lots of traffic and big shoulder.
Was pretty late and was just hanging out asking for rides. Ended up catching one to Newark and then took transit into NYC
Big shoulder room to stop, mostly local rides but should still get you 20-30 miles
Big shoulder room to pull over easily after stop light, mostly local rides it seems
Picked up right away by a nice German guy with a fancy car, thumed by the on ramp.
Got picked up by the first car I asked in the gas station, two nice South American guys. Slightly shady walking to the gas station from downtown Ft. Myers, probably because it was night.
Room to stop , lots of tourists from bar harbor won't stop for ya, but locals might, ask at the gas station to. Got a ride to ellensworth
Got a ride to the MAX station in Gresham pretty quick. Good vibes on 84 coming into Portland.
Good spot for a hitch into Montpelier
Fine as far as Interstate hitching goes. Idaho can be tough with the cops but luckily a van pulled over headed to Boise.
Quick lift to Glenn's Ferry from a guy who'd been living there since the 80s but leaves for LA every October because he hates the cold.
Short wait and the guy that picked me up took me right to my destination in south Jordan.
Short ride to Wanship. Be careful because the off-ramp and the on-ramp are a mile apart on 80 west. I ended up standing on the freeway.
Nice people in Utica. Eventually a guy named Seth stopped. Doordashing and took me to the Interstate in York.
Short ride to Omaha. Probably not worth holding out for something better.
Good commuter ride going to Council Bluffs
Tons of people stopped to say their car was too full. Good vibes. Friday and Saturday 11-2 you might see a church group giving out food for donations. Hot dogs :)
Last winter used this spot, the wait was like an hour. Fickle. Most traffic is going into Boston obv.
Very dead ramp but you never can tell. Ride from a landscaping guy all the way to Desoto. Watched the sun set over the endless corn.
Ride from a nice couple who weren't going anywhere and took me a couple miles.
First ride in Iowa from a geologist dude to Iowa city. I felt bad I didn't have more time to spend in Iowa City as it sounds like a cool spot.
Local couple picked me up was very talkative. Said they only listen to CDs and mostly eat beans and hot dogs since Trump got elected.
Short ride to Rule from a guy who does tree maintenance for roads and power lines. Complaining about property owners who don't want their trees to be removed.
Ride to Aspermont from a guy headed to Abilene for a cornhole tournament. He had to stop at the liquor store because he doesn't throw as well when he's sober.
Short ride from an oil field guy to Jayton. He's got 7 kids out here. Starts work every day at 4:00. Wakes up at 3:30.
Plenty of nice people in west Texas, you might just have to wait awhile. Lots of local rides on 380 because most of the long distance traffic is down on I-20 at that point.
I-25 in this part of Colorado is VERY dead. Best bet is to stand on the interstate. Toward evening there were maybe two or three cars per minute. Eventually a guy stopped going to Raton.
Not a bad spot. Caught a ride going all the way past Pinedale

Started at the gas station nearby flying a sign, almost got a ride to KC but didnt work out, eventually moved to the onramp and got picked up in 30- an hour. on 70, decent amount of people getting on east, this guy seemed keen to take hitchers.

Plenty of shoulder if you walk a little past the light. Cars are going fast, but!, they can see you at a distance and the ones caught at the light have even more time to consider pulling over. I caught a ride all the way to Colorado from here.
Local traffic for the most part up here. Short ride from a dude headed home. I left my lucky hat in his car / - :
September 2024, not easy but there are still kind and hospitable people in New York state  :)
September 2024, 11:20 a.m.
September 2024, 17:30, a kind old man stopped
September 2024, 15:30, hitchhiking in USA is difficult, but New York State and New England are some of the best areas
Many cars, great spot to pull off.
Quick ride to the gas station from a couple of highschoolers.
Slow hitching in Tupelo
Slow morning hitch. Got a ride from a preschool teacher going to Lewes.
Lots of traffic on Rt 1 but Delaware residents are a little shy. Thumbed a Tesla to Odessa.
The spot is pretty good. Slower traffic and good pullout. The cops stopped just after the driver did, second time this happened to us in NJ. They let us all go and told us not to walk on the freeway.

The spot is pretty good for a freeway hitch. Cops stopped because they heard reports of a dirt bike on the freeway. We didn't have a dirt bike but they advised us not to hitchhike on the interstate and they drove us to the Wawa out by Six Flags.
Couple of hispanic guys took us to the train station at Bridgeport. We decided to take public transit the rest of the way into NY.
Lots of traffic. Eventually a kid stopped who was going to Bangor.
Ride from a Puerto Rican Uber driver. He said he never stops to help anybody but he'll help us. Got us past Harrisburg.
Ride from a guy in a pickup truck with a dog named Jolene. Brought us out past Harrisonburg then turned around.
Good spot, lots of traffic. Not too much pullout but fine. Ride from a guy going all the way to Maryland. A shame we were just going to Knoxville!
Good spot. Lot's of traffic. Took awhile for someone to bite. Got an Indian guy with Buddha on the dash going to Crossville.
Quick ride to the edge of Jonesboro. Jonesboro is tough to hitch through but we made do.
Spot was not great but this area of Arkansas just seems very hitchhiker-friendly.
Got picked up by a vet missing half his arm. Kept making weird sex jokes and calling people while steering with the half-arm. Let us off in Alpena and got us pizza from the gas station.
The light by the onramp is a great place to hitchhike. Good pullout and plenty of time to make eye contact. Got a quick ride farther into the tornado warning.

Lots of traffic, but not very easy for cars to stop.  I first tried waiting along the road, then I tried on the on-ramp and got a ride pretty quick.  I flew a sign that said “HOOKSETT/BOSTON.”  I think people often ignore people holding cardboard signs, because they assume you are just asking for money and don’t really read it, so if you do fly a sign, make the letters really big.

Walked from Carroll & Highland to Carroll & Hickory, thumbs out & finally got a ride near Hickory that took me all the way to University, asked immediately if I was dangerous and I said no. She drove me to Ave C after flipping around, and told me her mom had a break in, and her mom told (like screamed from the other room at ) the ppl breaking in that she believed in Jesus and they left !

Got a ride while hitching near the side of the road, by the light. Night ride. The dude who ended up picking me up backed up after stopping to turn right. Raised pick up truck, offered to drive me further than he did and also offered me a beer. A pretty good spot on University for going East or South, but mostly bc I was okay going either way.

Got a ride from a friend of a friend to the college of music from the environmental science building. We walked to her car before she drove me. I did not remember meeting her before, but she was super cool, & works at a dispo. Many cars passed me on Ave C & Hickory before she walked up- sometimes the ride isn't even on wheels yet.

Got picked up on the third round of traffic lights on Oak. Not a perfect spot, but like many local rides near UNT, there are many students willing to pick you up on the way home or to school. I got a ride from an Indian couple from Telangana and they offered to take me all the way past the interstate, where they were headed home. There's a little area for a car to pull in near where I hitched, but they just stayed in the street.

I've thumbed in this spot before without any luck, but have had lots of success recently. Anywhere on Ave C, there are people who will pick you up, mostly people from other countries or chill UNT students. I got a ride from a UNT worker from India to Bruce Hall where he turned, and later that day I was here and my roommate happened to pick me up- I mention that here as it won't garner a second hitch review & and it was on the same day.  
At the music building there is also a good spot right nea
25's. Good space to pull over, light traffic at this hour. Got a ride all the way to hickory
25's. Plenty of traffic, plenty of room to stop, even the cops didnt bother me (Hitchicking is forbiden in town)
25's. Picked up fast, but I asked too late how far they were going. Good spot otherwise.
25's. Good spot, plenty of room to stop, good traffic and make sure to be far enouth from curves for good visibility.
25's. Hitched all the way to Louisville from here, but it was raining: seems I got some sort of pitty ride
25's. Several ppl stopped but a lot of short rides. Seems like a good location
25's. Decent spot geographically, but people don't seem friendly. Got a middle finger here. Good traffic.
2guys, 25's, backpacks. Tried one asking at the gas station and one sticking thumb on the side of the road. Did not work at the gas station.

2guys, 25's. Hitched near a sign showing "Bishop", on out way, and pointed at it with a stick. Did it help ? Maybe. 
Got dropped off at  interchange CA178/US395 Bus towards Ridgecrest. Probably better to have stayed on the main highway 14.
Spot ok, slow traffic at dark. Got a short ride
Pretty good but not so long rides in the area
Busy petrol station with store and fast food. Good to ask for rides.
Small petrol station good to ask people. Got quickly a ride to St. Augustine.
No car actually stopped, but this lady came to us from the nearby store parking lot and took us further. Super friendly.
Convenient spot but people don't stop. Finally got a truck driver to stop and take us right to New Orleans. Pretty awesome
Nobody seems to pickup people here, but we finally got lucky. Rode in the back of a pickup truck.
Good visibility and space to stop. We got took by a super friendly cuban family for a short ride.
Good visibility, good space for cars to stop. We dropped our sign bc it was unsuccessful and then it worked. Apparently a lot of people going for short rides there.
A lot of traffic, not a lot of people stopping. Good visibility, good space to pull over. But strong traffic, I had a hard time keeping my thumb out, no downtime to rest my arm
This is a bold spot to hitch out of town, but it worked for me. Acceptable shoulder for drivers, low speed, steady traffic. Maybe better options elsewhere
Lots of easy short rides southbound to STL. Local commuters are nice. Be clean cut if possible

Surprised this spot wasn’t here, because it’s kinda obvious, so it took me about 40 minutes which is fine for rich area like this, you are in a good visibility for drivers and it goes uphill so they slow down.
Waited about 3 hours for a ride all the way to Amarillo. Not a bad spot for Interstate hitchhiking but the sun can be pretty brutal.
This spot is a little close to the police station, but no one gave me any trouble. The shoulder is wide so people can pull off. traffic is still moving pretty slow.
Folks up here are pretty chill. They're used to giving rides to PNT Through hikers.
Everybody is going to the grand canyon. Good place.
Lots of people just going to the next town. I took one of these but it may be worth waiting longer to go further than Fredonia
Good spot. Lots of people, across from a red light which forces people to slow. Place to stop. Directly heading to I-70.
Room to pull over!
Cars are going pretty fast but there's a breakdown lane, so it can work.

Decent spot to get onto US 101, as there's a largish gravel shoulder before the on-ramp where people can stop. First car which stopped (5 mins waiting) didn't go in my direction, second one (15 mins) took me all the way to the Port Angeles area. If you're not finding a ride, there's a bus station nearby, as well as places to buy drink and food.
Nice spot. Good people. Stinky me.
Next to gas station and they see you for a long time

15-20 minutes, which is not bad, but position not really good for a hitchhike. If you will go on ramp u will see the "no pedestrian blah blah blah" sign and others. So best strategy is to stay little before it and stay on corner. There is traffic light and long way before you. So drivers have a planty of time to see you.
I wasn looking for a place to hitchhike, but a guy on a truck just stop by and ask me if I'm hitchhiking
Best spot around. Near a gas station, straight long route, awesome visibility from far.
Very few people (3-5 cars per minute) but very kind.
Got a track really fast. Next to gas station which is also good
People coming from bar harbor really often and like hitchhikers (or I'm just lucky)
Not a bad spot at all, although not much shade. Was picked up by a really kind man who took me all the way to McAllen
Pretty decent spot, lots of gas stations

The on ramp here was pretty dead, most of the traffic is going north and then either headed east or west along the 80. Eventually walked on the interstate and flew a sign there. More traffic will see you, but speed limit in this area was 70-75, so I wouldn't expect many people to stop here. The couple that picked me up said they drove past at first and then decided to come back around and pick me up. Got a straight ride to Denver though. Can't remember how long it took as I was walking along the
Not a bad spot at all - got across the whole of Arkansas in one trip and was dropped in Rockwall, Tx
Decent spot with a fair amount of traffic. Picked up by a friendly old school trucker called Hank who took us all the way to Athens, Al! One guy one girl

Sat right at the truck parking lot exit, held out my sign when I saw trucks driving out. First one that stopped said they were headed in the opposite direction, but another truck stopped a little while later and gave me a ride out. Much faster here than the on ramp and more responses.
Just before here two lines merge together, making the cats go slow, and there is space to stop
Good spot, plenty of traffic and room for cars to pull over. Bus station close by to charge phone. Free food Cafe close by as well. Next to friendship house.

Used this location prior to the disassembly of the oasis (highway overpass rest-stop). Knocked on semi-truck doors until someone offered a ride.  Gas stations still exist here, so maybe still an option, but most likely less trucks now.
Decent spot by the railroad crossing
Ski traffic, might not get you too far
Nice people, got waved at by most who just passed, good space for cars to pull off
Rochester to Niagara Falls, I was lucky i guess
This spot is Ok. Pretty typical. With a bunch of Cartel activity in the area.Yakima is a pretty rough city, so if you're passing through and heading north, try to get dropped off here.
Hitching right off of the highway might be your best bet if you get dropped off at this ramp. The road is pretty fast here, but the shoulder is wide, and the visibility is good.
The ramp is ok. Lots of room to pull off.

This spot is ok. There isn't a whole lot of traffic, but there is plenty of room to pull off. There is a good place to sit here. The other northbound ramp gets more traffic, but this ramp has better visibility, and a place to sit.
Guy who picked me up asked me to drive, then went to sleep while I was driving.

This isn't the perfect spot, but if you're stuck out here in Melissa, then it's probably your best bet. I find that the type of person that stops at Buccie's, isn't the type of person that stops for hitchhikers. 

That said, people that live in Melissa are even less likely to stop for you. I got picked up by a California transplant, that does a lot of backpacking. He was a really cool guy. He was on his way out to Texoma lake to test out some new gear.
It's a little ways out of town, but it's a pretty good spot.
Took a min to get a ride but got one all the way into Swansea

I walked here from Fife. It was well worth the walk.

There is a ton of room for cars to pull off. A retaining wall partially blocks the view for some of the oncoming traffic, but they still have plenty of time and room to stop. I got picked up really quickly by a guy that ended up buying a bus ticket for me to portland, so I'd call it a win.
People were chill about it but it took a few cars. Got a ride from a construction worker heading into San Fran

call my mom. email me for her number with where youre at, if youre stuck, etc. she lives in town but often goes to phoenix, vegas, indio or santa barbara depending on what she's doing.
abolition666@protonmail.com
let me know you got this info from hitchwiki
Truck stop
I was waiting with an LA sign close to the Taco Bell parking lot and was picked up after about 15min to get to UCLA
Got a short lift to San Luis Obispo in no time in the morning.
The truckers at this truckstop are pretty unfriendly. As long as you don't fly a sign, the staff doesn't care that you're there
Took the bus from SLO to Morro Bay and got a short ride North on the 1 within 10 minutes. It was easy to get picked up.
Going north is wicked easy, but getting a ride south is like pulling teeth.
There's a parking lot for buses opposite to the Subway restaurant. Right at a four way light crossing. Great spot. Just don't take a ride shorter than Coos Bay. There's almost nothing along Hwy 42..
Despite the dark, I got a lift to Princeville so I could shop without having to get off the bus and wait and hour for the next one.
In front of post office/bus stop. Get a ride to haena or kalalau. Wait 20-30 minutes.

Quick ride from a trucker who was goin to SD. Got off in Grand Island. He was watching South Park while he drove. Gave me two sausage egg McMuffins that he had just bought but insisted that he had no interest in ever eating.
Got a ride all the way to Cheyenne from here pretty easily. Hitching the midwest after college move-in weekends is a good thing.

Decent spot. Took about two hours to find a ride. Police drove by a few times but didn't bother me. Hitching in PA is against the law but seems to be rarely enforced. Another driver gave me $20 too before I found my ride.

I HH here to Harrisburg (about 1-1.5 hours ride).
It is possible for the cars to stop on the on ramp to pick you up. 

How to get here?
It is a bit tricky I was partly HH and walking from the Allentwon Greyhound bus terminal. Takes some time but the spot is good. Trafic is not too much but cares are not very fast since there is a redlight nearby to slow them down
Probably just really licked out but got a ride to Ashland within 10-15 minutes.
The spot seems perfect, but I was waiting for over 2 hours and nobody would stop. Maybe I was out of luck. I went to the airport blvd ramp and got picked after 40 mins.
Good spot. only spent about 30 minutes here before i got a ride. got harassed by some coppers, but they didn't come back to check if i was still there.

There is plenty of time for people to see you and stop, and there is a lot of room for cars and trucks to pull off. I leaned against one of the highway sign poles and waited. Wasn't that long of a wait.
Southbound. Not the worst spot ever. Cars and trucks stop through here on their way to/from Chico or for gas & fast food.

I waited 8 hrs with no ride. I can see how this would be a good spot, but the traffic was mostly teslas, BMWs, and Lexus'.

Maybe I just picked a bad day to hitch.
Got out surprisingly fast. Right under the arches of the I5 bridge
Going southbound, this is your spot. Good viewing distance, good Portland folks. Making a sign may be helpful. Look for the hippie vans!
Got a ride to Trinidad relatively quick

Arcata's a cool town and all, but you can't hitch north out of it. We tried for nearly 6 hours, and a few people stopped and told us it was a tough hitch, but nobody picked us up. (we had a sign for Crescent City) You're better off on the side of the 5, even though cars are going really fast there. People are nice, but nobody's going anywhere.
If you'reheading east, go for any ride going to Blue Lake or Willow Creek -- both have better 299 hitch spots and will get you outof the local traffic zone
Evidently a popular spot (signs strewn around, other hitchers joined us while we waited) but traffic was almost entirely local, to McKinleyville etc.  Eventually took a ride to Trinidad.
We waited here four hours then took the $3 vista bus to santa barbara; gotten lucky here before though.
I waited there 3 hours before giving up.

Seemed like an OK spot to me. Figured most people would be going long distance, and I got a decent amount of traffic, but very few stopped. Just think SoCal is rough for hitching. Got a ride in 2 hours to Santa Barbara.
Decent it is. Low traffic as well, this may help however. Got a short ride to Summerland.
The on-ramp here is a pretty decent spot if a bit under-trafficked, drivers can see you from quite a distance away and most drivers seem to be heading relatively far.

A few folks stopped, but they were pretty short rides. I got a few kick downs. Smokes and donuts. The ramp has a curb, but there is a wide shoulder on the highway. Although traffic is moving pretty quickly, and no one seemed to want to stop.

I left the spot because of construction. I agree, it seems like the other ramp in town may be better for both north and south bound traffic. Although if someone offers a ride out to Pleasant Valley (north), you could ask to get dropped off at the Manzanit

Going north, we were told this is much better than the other Grant's Pass onramp, but the shoulder on the onramp is pretty narrow and we waited two hours without anybody stopping.  Probably better to ask people at the adjacent gas stations.

I waited about 30 minutes on a Sunday afternoon (just before sunset) with a sign that said Victorville.  Getting a lift farther could be difficult because most traffic is "local," leaving Ontatio Mills from a day of shopping.  To get lifts from here, you'll have to be relatively clean looking.
waited for 3 hours, got a ride 2 minutes down the road to Slidell. Not a lot of cars here, locals seem apprehensive to pick up strangers.
Waited 2 hours, got a ride to Slidell (not that far.) Seemed like a lot of local traffic, cops didn't care.
Waited for 2h and was going to Knoxville, TN (sign "I-59N"). Many cars going to Texas. Police didn't bother. It's easy to get there: bus 62,64,65 till Bullard Ave/Walmart
Waited here about 20 minutes for a ride to Vancouver WA. Got offered coins twice!

Easy to get to with public transit and a bit of walking. The traffic was crawling when I hitched here. During the 45 minutes I waited, I received four offers, all of which were heading to Vancouver. I scribbled a sign that said "Olympia" and within five minutes I had an awesome ride to Olympia.

Not such a great spot, but I've never found hitching north outta Portland to be all that easy. Cars have room to stop and if traffic is backed up, you can ask around at stopped cars. We waited one and a half hours.
I've waited a few times in front of the Sizzler, I usually get picked up within the first twenty minutes. Not an ideal spot, but with a sign it works.
Decent spot. Waited about an hour. Stand near the MVD(adot) building.
Decent spot to get a ride to Phoenix. A sign is helpful here. Average wait is 30 - 60 min.
This is not a bad spot for catching a ride west. Plenty of space for rides to pull over, but there are no places for food and water.
Fuck cloverdale
I waited a little while here, but overall, this seems like a very common spot to hitch.
04/2013 We stood there for about an hour before getting a lift to the outskirts of LA. Wouldn't go there during summer (hot hot hot).

05/23/2013
Had a hell of a time getting a lift -- 6 hours to go just a few miles south.  Seems that people aren't very receptive to hitchhikers here.  Lately there have been an outpouring of highway patrol (probably because of Memorial Day).  I'd just avoid the Vegas area at all costs; it really sucks!

Decent spot for hitchhiking south on interestate - 15.  I didn't use a sign because it's fairly obvious I'd like to go somewhere south, and it seems that most people are either going to Stateline or California.  I did wait about an hour or two because there was heavy traffic which makes for grumpy drivers.

Eastbound. Three bus rides, one of them free, will get you here from Portland. (Ask the drivers where to transfer.) A good place for trips to Bend or Mount Hood area camping spots. Right around the corner are a grocery, liquor store, and library - everything a traveler needs.

A lot of trucks. Nobody stopped when in was dark even though stood on the ramp for 4 hours. Spent the night sleeping in the nearby bushes. Started hitchhiking again early morning. Took good 4 hours to be picked up by a Russian bus driver.
Onramp heading south. Waited here just in front of the "No Hitchhiking" sign and got a ride within about 20 minutes.

Pretty solid place, serves both directions(which are to the best of my recollection on separate parking lots). Lots of Quebecois, although mostly with full cars (I was told they were returning from Florida). Declined a couple of shorter rides until eventually settling for a ride with a Vermonter who took me all the way to Glens Falls. The I-87 gets very lonely North of Glens Falls.
-uncle_sam01

There may be legal issues to hitching from this thruway service area, but nobody bothered me standing by the door with my sign.  A lot of traffic going a long way stops here, and it definitely beats being stuck in Albany.  After a bit over an hour got a ride through to Burlington, Vermont.

Not the best spot to get a lift along 191, .... like the dude said.... cause it's at a bend in the road but it IS a great spot to hitch a ride into Arches NP. Maybe you can pitch in $5 for the fee but people will probably just be like 'ayyyyy whatev, you cool.' great place to make travelling friends
Bad spot. No shade at all. Tourists from the arches, tourists from Moab, speeding up on the US 191, there's no way they can slow down and see your sign. After a hour a guy going to salt lake stopped.

Headed south on a Sunday around noon. Waited for about 20 minutes, and got a ride. Decent amount of traffic.

(female, 20s)

Started hitching South around 9am on a Sunday morning, had to take cover a few times due to rain. Got a lift around 10, but probably only spent about 20 minutes legitimately hitchhiking. Held a sign for I-75S, because the road splits. There's no good place to pull off, but there's a stop light, so it works out. Also noteworthy, I was passed by several cops who didn't bother me =)

(female, 20s)

Headed east, got a ride all the way to Ohio. Waited an hour and a half on a Wednesday morning. Nobody stopped for me, but finally a guest who had stayed at the hotel right there call over and offer a lift. 

(female, 20s)

Headed towards Ohio. It's a poor spot as far as pulling off is concerned. But there is a decent amount of traffic. Got a ride in maybe 20 minutes to exit 136.

(female, 20s)
Too high speed through her. Walked and thumbed for over an hour.

Headed to Chicago. Got a ride to Jaynesville in about 10 minutes. Thumbing around 2pm on a Thursday.

(female, 20s)

Headed to Chicago, not the greatest location. Poor traffic, cars headed to different highways just ahead. Did catch a ride after about 10 minutes, not going to far...

(female, 20s)

Headed to Geneva (fourteen miles down Randall). Totally half-heartedly thumbed for about 10 minutes then gave up. Had a guy catch up with me at 7-11 and drop me exactly where I needed to go.

(female, 20s)

Headed to Chicago. Kind of an awkward place to stand, there is no good place for cars to pull off, but there's a decent amount of traffic. Got a semi all the way within 5 minutes. Held a sign for "Illinois". 3:30 on a Thursday. 

(female, 20s)

Headed to Chicago, got a ride to Jaynesville in about 20 minutes. Thumbing at 11:45 on a Thursday. 

(female, 20s)

Headed toward Chicago. Barely any traffic on a Thursday at 11am. But, got a ride to Tomah after 20 minutes thumbing.

(female, 20s)

Fortuna sucks balls. Tried every on-ramp in town. This--the last one--was good traffic, but mostly vacationers. 
Once I settled into the prime spot, I waited no more than 30 mins.
Took about 50 mins to get out of here.

Heading East, got a ride to Sioux Falls after about an hour (Thursday at 8am). In general doesn't seem like people are too receptive to hitchhiking here, though. Thumbed for awhile, then held a sign for Sioux Falls.

(female, 20s)

Got dropped here around 6pm at the south end of town Cool beach shortcut to the next shoulder. Rad culvert you can walk through. Tried for one last ride before night. No luck. Really enjoyed camping here.
Woke up to weekend traffic, but a local grabbed me. Started at 7am. Didn't get a ride 'til 10. 
Nice turnout for pulling over. Guessing this spot is hit or miss.
Was good for me. 10 min wait."Steve" was headed south, but turned around for me. Short ride to Port Orford. Nice camp spots there,
Wasn't too hard hitching out of Bandon - especially considering it was 7am and foggy as hell. If you get a ride, try to make sure it gets you past Port Orford though.

This location has decent traffic and I got picked up in around 2 hours.  I tried to get a ride all the way to Denver, but the ride only took me to Buffalo, WY.  It was actually an entire family on their vacation!  How weird.  Anyways, not a horrible spot, but it was super sunny and windy!

This is the location of the largest truck stop in the world!  People that don't hitchhike think that getting rides from truckers is super easy because they go so far, but the truth is that many of them have insurance reasons that they can't pick people up.  I got fooled 3 times at this location from truckers that were pulling over on the shoulder of the on-ramp, but they were not pulling over for me.  After about 2 hours in the hot sun, I got a woman to give me a ride for about a half an hour do

Got a short ride after about 45 minutes.  The guy even had his son in the car!  Never felt unsafe, but the guy was asking me my religious views within 10 minutes of picking me up.  I think a lot of people in Michigan want to spread the word of God to hitchhikers.

Lots of traffic, waited less than 2 hours and got offered 3 rides, only took the last one.  The first to pull over was really abrasive and the second could only give me a ride a couple hours later.  The person I ended up hitching with only took me to the next exit.  Be aware that hitching in Michigan will usually only get you short rides.

Headed East towards South Dakota. Pretty decent location on a Tuesday at 2pm. Got a semi all the way to Rapid City within 15 minutes. 

Recommend holding a sign, as the road just ahead splits into two East-headed highways.

(female, 20s)

Headed East. Great physical location (plenty of room to be seen and to pull off), but poor traffic levels at 12pm on a Tuesday. Still, got a ride to Billings within a minute.

(female, 20s)

Headed East, got a ride to Livingston. Mostly disinterested drivers, but I did get a ride after about 30 minutes. 

(female, 20s)

Heading west to Missoula. In theory not the best setup, it's a weird traffic pattern with not much traffic. 

That said, I had two offers to Couer d'Alene, and an offer to have a bus ticket purchased for me before I got a lift. All in all I waited less than half an hour. Starting at 9:45 on a Wednesday morning.

Held a sign for Montana <3
(clean, twenties, female)

On ramp heading East. I started at 9:30 on a Tuesday morning and had a ride towards Coeur d'Alene within ten minutes. Ended up only going to just before the Washington/Idaho border, since I didn't want to mess with hitching in Idaho. 

(clean, twenties, female)
About 2 hours , lift almost to my destination , seward ,  actually been droped 10 miles before then got another lift quicly !
Heading West, slow going but people passing through will see you from the off-ramp.
Only people who have a chance to consider ate the cars stopped on the bridge. Lots of old people, hard to get a ride.
Way to North. I stayed here 15 minutes before got ride out of the city. People will be suppressed you are staying here. But it works.

I stayed here two hours. By my opinion very comfortable place, a lot of trucks going to main road from here to the way San Antonio. But because American don't like hitchhikers, probably it will takes some time.
there's a macdonalds and gas station here, mostly local traffic
If you're heading south, spec. Bainbridge Island/Seattle, the spot by the bus-stop here is alright.
Decent spot, considering there's not much room on the sides of Hansville Road for a while if you're heading north. You're next best spot is near to the gas station/NE Little Boston Road.
Hitched north here in about 30 minutes. Marking average, because this place is way away from anything, in the farms, and people in Kansas suck in general.
Low traffic area, no rides for 2 days. The next exit west, the only other one, has a lot of traffic, and we got a ride in 2 hours.
Not a really nice area, but got a ride all the way to KC after 2 hours.

Most people here are heading to Little Rock, still,  it took a while to get a ride because it's a pretty ghettofied area. Store owners told me the threat of burglary was enough to warrant the need for personal firearms.
Directional or destination sign would probably be better here. College town up the road in the main part of town, so it's not the worst.
Cars going too fast to want to stop, and considering it's a yuppi-fied area, they kinda just all stare at you. Way better than the LA area, though.

Actually a horrible spot, but the stoplight gives you enough time to let a decent length of cars see and consider stipping on the very short stretch of shoulder that's wide enough to stop. Got picked up by an ex grower who brought me back to his house and smoked me the fuck out with his family, of all things.

seems like a bad spot, but I had finally just gotten off the spur interstate and said fuck it. Got picked up in 30 minutes. Marking this as average because I got lucky with a really old guy who used to hitchhike all the time, all over the continent.
Not very busy, and people drive locally, but be patient, and you'll get it!

Weird place. There are a couple of truck stops, but this entrance is just not busy at all. I find asking drivers directly in truck stops not very efficient in America (unlike Europe), but still hang out there for a while and then hit the on-ramp and thumb. It has happened a few times to me that people picked me up off the ramp cause they saw me hanging out at the truck stop.

Very, very small town. Only few cars actually hit the interstate here. I was very lucky as a hitchhiker from the town joined me and we were picked up shortly after by a friend of hers that drove by. She took us to Truckee.
Many people are driving locally, but still accept their rides, even if they're going 4 miles. Once you get farther from the Bay Area, you'll get longer rides.
The employees seem to be hitchhiking friendly, and had no problem with me asking people around the gas station. I got a ride to California after 2 hours and a half. Not very busy though

There is a truck stop with cafe (employees allowed me to sleep at table while raining) and also a rest area. Long highway on-ramps east and west directions, easy for truckers to pull over. Medium amount of vehicle traffic at ramps, can also approach cars at gas station/ truck stop.
Low traffic but decent space to pull off. Got a ride in 10 minutes.
