Hitched southbound in late afternoon in October. Tons of local traffic, waited a couple hours before getting a ride to Santa Rosa.
Got a great ride all the way to the southwest Oregon coast from here without waiting too long.
Long wait, cold morning, got a short ride south.

The police may gently encourage you to walk outside of the town limits. This is the point where, on my way to said limits, I got a ride to Jackson. The guy gave me a driving tour of the Grand Tetons on the way.
Waited a couple hours but got a ride towards northwest Wyoming from someone driving up from Denver. Not a lot of traffic in Laramie, but this is probably the best option.
Got a ride all the way to Cheyenne from here pretty easily. Hitching college towns after move-in weekends is a good idea.
My first hitch ever! After a couple hours I got a ride to Des Moines. People aren't used to hitchhikers here, but they're generally friendly.
Ride 20 miles, just as I stuck out my thumb, at this particular spot, but nobody picked me up on the way from the West to the East side of town.
2 hour wait, but it was later morning and still very foggy. Got ride to Clarksville.
Try earlier in the day for better luck.
There don't seem to be many good hitching spots south out of Olympia, but this place is ok. Wide shoulder and close to downtown.
Got a ride within 15 minutes to the nearest truck stop. Guy was a straight  up thiging drug dealer.

Mile 276: Tatlanika Gift Shop

I waited 3 hours in the rain and sleet here on the side of the road day after all the birds flew south for the winter. My sign said ANC on it and they took me half way there.
There isn't too much space for a car to stop, but it'll work.  Street view: https://goo.gl/maps/VZwsmjLeo412
Sparky's gas, restaurant, gifts. Sit on the stairs with a sign. You might want to be a customer, they're funny about loiters.
There's an Amtrak and Greyhound station. Hitching isn't too hard.
Don't think it's good hitchin' here. I got lucky and had someone coming from Cadott, east of here, pick me up and take me there because her daughter saw my dog and felt bad.
Waited an hour got a ride from a crazy lady ( good kind of crazy ) who took me 7 hours into NE. Got me so drunk I puked. Good times.
Death marching to Jackson got a ride all the way to to South Sioux city on the border from a migrant worker.
Waited an hour during morning rush  just thumbing it. Cops don't care about you being here.
Had no hitchhiking signs that were clearly visible. Flew out "PLEASE" sign with thumb out and got ride east to Ellensburg after 45 minutes.
Little traffic, but some locals are willing to drive you to the next town over.
For I-95 north
A bad place to hitch I-95 north; people are going too fast already.
A more industrial area, with more trucks, but they don't stop a lot anyway.
In direction of San Diego. We had to wait 30 minutes for two people (one guy and one girl) before being picked up by a 24 years old girl going to south of San Diego.
hitched nearly six hours...no public trasport... go to hell tracy
Very bad area for pickups, many tourists just headed to Disney World.

Got my first ride 15 minutes into the trip from simply walking on the side of the road with my pack, no thumb out. This area is populated with many college students, some who are more inclined and open minded to pick up hitchers.
not amazing. even after pulling out the violin it took a while to get a ride. you will get one just be patient
Pilot/Flying J truck stop at exit 7
Good way to get on I-78 W from NYC.  You can take NJTransit from Penn Station to Annandale for $15.
I didn't actually get a ride here, but I only tried for about 15 minutes because I had some time until the bus to Centreville arrived.
Not the best spot. Drivers have little time to see you and little room to stop, but it should be possible to get a ride from here. Positioning yourself well would be key.
Wanted to go south on Turnpike, quick trafficlights, lots of dust, impossible

Wanted to go west to Newark,
Lots of Beggars but eventually alright
30 minutes

Wanted to go West on I-78
Traffic lights, lots of cars, easy
5minutes
A long 2,5 hour wait for a ride just a few miles west. 90% of traffic just local. Got driven out of the city fortunately and got a next ride to Denali within 15 minutes.

Hitching towards Denali, Anchorage.

Not the greatest spot, most of traffic is just local. There's some place to pull over, but the sport is after a turn, so drivers cannot see you from very far. They still can see you though.

On a friday afternoon, a couple, we got some hard time there under the rain even if the location is good (visibility and space to pull over), people around werent't really friendly with 2 hitchhikers from France.
Waited a few hours, asking people at the gas station near by (and finally getting kicked out for loitering but we could hang out the burger king or the mcdonald across the hwy), we finally got a short ride going east :)

Good place to hitch, many cars passing by. It's NJ so be aware of police but to be honest, when I was standing there, one police car passed me and they only waved to me to go away, but they didn't even stop. I was waiting for 1 hour.

Not a great spot. Waited 2 hours and got hassled by police. But there is plenty of room for cars to pull over, you'll get a lift here to a better on ramp further west at least, just might take some time.
Many people passing but not stopping, took just under two hours to get a ride to Ventura.
Waited over two hours, but people are pretty friendly and open minded so wait long enough here and you'll be able to catch a ride south.

This is not a bad place to get rides north. I waited an hour and 30 mins, then decide to walk 3 miles to the next on-ramp, it worked out well for me but this is a much better place to hitch north than the next on-ramp.
Not too bad a place to hitch a ride north to Salt Lake. People getting on here are potentially heading far north. Took just over an hour to hitch a ride north here.
Good place to hitch a ride going north but it's mostly locals. Would probably better heading south as this is on the south side of the city.
Really good place to Hitchhike north to Las Vegas. Took 20 minutes to hitch a ride from here.

Not great as there's little room for cars to pull over. Took 40 mins. Got a lift a little further south to Tusayan, where there is a good spot just outside the airport there to Hitchhike south to Flagstaff.
Not great, not that many people using this on-ramp to travel west. But there is room for cars to pull over, so just need a bit of luck.
You can ask truckers filling up gas for rides. Most are going east but I found one going west and got all the way to Bozeman, MT.

San Diego is a good city to find hitchers at. Very friendly people. Getting picked up is just a luck of the draw for newbies, but if you know what you are doing, you can get one withint like 160 minutes or less

Entrance to i-5, south direction.

30 min wait
Tried to get a ride to Columbia, not a ton of success, but a comfortable space to wait with a pulloff area.
Tons of cars entering the highway here, though most are commuters.  You can definitely land a ride to Sacramento if you have a sign, but further than that might be a stretch from this location.
Nice straight spot but not a lot of shoulder, not too many cars and not as friendly either. Had to wait maybe 30-40 minutes for a ride but got one all the way down to California
Farmers look at you funny and not much traffic but plenty of shoulder and a good view of the blimp hanger. Waited maybe 25 minutes.
No good place to stop, people seemed down but just shrugged their shoulders, after about 20 minutes a guy made a uturn to pick us up in the parking lot across

Crazy bridge crossing, no shoulder or side walk, best try to hitch across it, chased out of longview by meth addicts in the night, this spot isn't great, lots of cars, can see you for awhile, but no good place to stop, waited about half and hour
Not too bad. Fast moving cars, but a good turn off spot if you're moving south

Direction: Westbound on 22 towards allentown

Spot about 300m away from the light, cars will go by slowly here and theres a non traffic lane for cars to pull over. Got picked up in 10 minutes. Cheers!
Not that much space, but the 101-n onramp near the tunnel worked for us, we got a ride offer in about twenty minutes.
Little traffic, but got a ride north eventually
Heading north on 17 had to wait for about 30 minutes but got a ride all the way to chief mountain customs.
Heading north on 89 fair amount of traffic but only short trips.
Heading north on 89, not to bad of a spot but no one is going to far out here.

There is a rest area on this exit, don't stand on the ramp, there are just a few trucks passing by and locals who go back to town. Try to ask at the gas station, I found someone who could take me to Grand Junction after two hours.

Compared to other towns on the rockies, it's a bad hitchiking town, I had to wait at least an hour, then I just decided to move towards the gas station and someone at the light picked me up. Plenty of room to pull over, but no cars stopping.
take the route 16 to west colfax and get off by the I 70 if you wanna go west
RTD bus is super cheap if need be. gettin out of denver is a hassle unless by bus. its 5 dollars though so no big deal.
Be friendly to the subway girl, when she got off from work she took me downtown Denver. It's near a big city, not a good place.
I stood there for 15 minutes, police pulled over because someone called them, they thought I was a runaway, they gave me a ride to a big truck area 15 miles out of omaha.

Came in on a Megabus from Chicago, Sunday morning, saw guy sitting there with sign. When I got there an hour later he was gone, so stood in same spot and got a ride west within an hour. Lots of traffic going both directions, east should be fine too.

2 hours, got a ride all the way to nashville. One other person stopped but didn't want to take my dog.
Pretty highly trafficed with decent possibility of long distance drivers.

Hitched right across the intersection from two state troopers directing traffic, they had no problem with me.  Lots of traffic from the outlet mall, mostly going south but got a ride to New Paltz in under an hour,
Most traffic here seems quite local.  After about 90 minutes I moved to the end of Jerome Ave to hitch onto the Deegan, which worked better.
I wanted to rich Canada and it seemed to be quite good place to go out of the town. I just had to take the subway 1 until the end and walk 5 minutes. I waited there on hour.

Do NOT let the cops tell you that hitchhiking is illegal in Iowa. State law says that law enforcement cannot stop you as long as you are off to the shoulder. 

This truck stop is very friendly. Be weary there is a state prison within ten miles of here. Check out the hilarious traveler
s graffitti in the underpass and help cross out some of the Nazi ramblings while your at it!
Wealthy area. A cop bothered me about the legality of hitchhiking and suggested I walk. But I gave him a good laugh and he "allowed" me to keep going so long as he didn't see me doing it again.
Try and get out of Park City area. This is a really wealthy area and it took 3+ hours to get my first ride out of here.
Helena is not my favorite place to begin with so I might be slightly bias. Still waited less than an hour.

Whether going East or West, expect a decent wait.. I was heading West and had a sign, although it was local traffic. Had to make a new sign and eventually an RV pulled over going to Yellowstone. Be careful what destination you write on our sign but you will get a ride.
A decent waiting time, a lot of tourists too. I happened to get a ride from a local into Spearfish. Just have a sign, and you'll be fine.

Whether going East or West, expect a good wait unless you get lucky. I was heading West, although the clerk at the truck stop kicked me out for writing on a piece of cardboard. 
I would just get on the on ramp with a sign and you will eventually get a ride.
Oh we took a 1.5$ bus to come here, from Crescent

Friday, from 8am, Going East, hitchhiked in front of this convenience store (nice people) and got picked up around 11am but directly to Portland ! The guy picked us up in his company truck on his way home.
2 guys with big bagpacks, but nice smiles xD

Walked from the HW 101 with our thumb on the road, no luck for 1 hour and then picked up. Not the best place because the road is pretty narrow all the way but do-able ! Dropped 50 or 60 miles further.
(2 guys with big bagpacks)

Worth noting, Mt. Pleasant, TX has a local ordinance banning hitchhiking, although it is not illegal in the state.  I was hassled by the cops there, but they ended up giving me a ride to the edge of town.

I rode US-65 through all of northern Arkansas, and overall the hitching wasn't bad, but there were many spots without good/any shoulders, so I did a lot of walking.  Usually the rides came without too much delay, but I did get stuck in Marshall, AR for about 3 hours.
Waited 45 min. for a longer ride. (was offered a short ride too). The spot is pretty good. Cars have to read your sign from 20 meters.
decent spot, lots of room for cars to pull over, took me about 20 minutes to get a ride, and right but an intersection so cars can see you in advance.
Right by the onramp on to the I-5. Ok traffic going north. Probably none of it very far. I think we just got lucky. Hitching out of cities is hard.
Not bad for getting a lift to Arizona ... best to have a sign and look clean.
This seems like the best place near this exit to get out of oxnard. That being said, oxnard isn't a very good place to be.

This place and the one above are pretty bad. Not much room for cars to see you, not much room for them to pull over. We waited about 1.5 hours then got super lucky with someone who took us all the way to Santa Cruz, but it seems like a bad place to be stuck. Not much traffic going north.
Nothing special, but plenty of space on the side of the on ramp for cars to stop.
Totally agree!  Got yelled at a couple of times and asked to leave, but caught a ride just as I was walking off the site.  Just be visible.
Large truckstop. Good for rides north or south. You may be thrown out if you're asking for rides, but we sat around with a sign near the entrance and had no problems. (Don't be an asshole.)
onramp of 203 merging onto 395.

I had the worst time trying to hitch from here. It was mostly local traffic and no one seemed at all interested in stopping. Waited over four hours before deciding to head back to Santa Barbara and try near the university.

Going north. A bit tricky to hitch as there isn't a sidewalk, making this spot illegal. Still, I've seen, picked-up, and got a lift here in relatively good time. I have a feeling it's a dependable place.
Eastbound. A decent enough hitching spot on a curvy, beautiful road.

Going north. People get the drift that you're just traveling up the coast. All the same, there are some older people in this area who aren't super keen on picking you up. However, there are also the baby-boomer locals who used to hitch back in their day. I might try Cayucos drive before this spot, but it was decent all the same.
Not the ideal place. All the same, you can get lucky with tourists or perhaps migrant workers like I did.
Not great, but get's the job done if you're lucky. There's a truck stop across the way but I didn't try talking to anyone. It has decent traffic and people have the opportunity to see you.
If going to Abbotsford Canada, unlikely you'll get a ride over the boarder, but having a sign saying you're Canadian, may help
Not too much traffic, but you're outside of the city and past where 275 breaks off, so people are more likely to be heading a long direction. Wait time was around 45 minutes to an hour.
It might not seem like the best spot, because it's on a curve, but I got picked up here after only 15 minutes or so.
The on-ramp leading to the I-25 East is a pretty good spot to catch a ride, a lot of truckers stop at the taco bell parking lot here, and I managed to get a ride to Albuquerque in less than an hour.
It was our first stop after a 20euro bus from Barcelona- we met a nice local who took us to first pieage- Magic, but i think its a slow city to hitch from-

Hitching out of inner-city Detroit can be kind of rough, but this spot gets lots of medium-distance traffic from students and workers at the university. Safe during the day, but I'm not sure I'd walk around by myself with a pack here after dark.
A rather long walk from Bangor, but you definitely want to be East of the end of I-395 to catch traffic going towards the coast.  Got a ride to Ellsworth in about half an hour.
Just past a traffic light, decent place to get rides north from Augusta.
Lots of traffic getting on I-295 here, going reasonably slowly because of the traffic light, but not a great spot to pull over.  Waited an hour for a ride north to Augusta.

Waited about 45 minutes here for a ride north up US1/I-95.  Not an ideal place to pull over, and only a fraction of the traffic actually getting on US1 near here, but I don't know of a better way northeast out of central Boston.

lots of traffic but mostly locals. waited 2 hours on ramp then said screw it and hopped on the road. got picked up 10 minutes after that.
lost of services here though.

good sized truck stop. Its a TA i think.
hitchin out is difficult. the ramp is dead and the shoulder on 70 isnt much better. 40 is a little easier but may drop you in a worse spot. great stop though. very nice lounge upstairs.
Got a ride on Saturday morning around 11 great hitchhiking.
Got a ride to Moscow around midnight from   some creeper, but a ride nonetheless
Lots of old people around here because of the lake. It's a really snobby town, according to the local that eventually picked me up.

This has not been the easiest spot in my past experience, but the South Weed exit is popular with both truckers and long distance drivers, so you will get a ride eventually, and probably this ride will be long distance. Camping is possible in the National Forest land across the railroad tracks, and the Black Butte Center for Railroad Culture is a 30 minute walk from this onramp. Note that none of the food-marts at this exit take food stamps, so if you're food stamp dependent, you'll have to walk

Avoid hitching west out of Sacramento by taking a Yolo Transit bus to Davis, and walking here, across the street from the In & Out Burger. For maximum visibility, stand on the triangular traffic island. Cars have plenty of room to stop. If you'd like a ride all the way to the East Bay, an "East Bay", "Oakland", or "BART" sign can help.

Northbound, I-29. Not much traffic, but this is nonetheless a good northbound hitching spot, as the ramp is wide, the university is nearby, and there is a truck stop, gas station, and fast food shop to attract long-distance traffic.
This is a welcome center for the state of Indiana.  The first guy I asked took me 216 miles to my final destination.

I-74E, I think I had just a bit of bad luck.  Some cars were stopping for me, but not going my direction.  There are two gas stations nearby though, so those are potentially good.  There is a welcome center about 5 miles E on I-74 so ask them to take you there.

There's a good spot heading east to sit right by the exit of the lot.  I caught a ride only going into a Flying J in the city where I got stuck for two days.  Definitely wish I'd stayed at this truck stop waiting for one out of Utah.
There are two truck stops here. Walk around asking enough, and you can easily find a ride to Reno, Oakland, or elsewhere. A bus from Salt Lake goes by, but I don't know which one.

I highly recommend walking down US-20 west with your thumb out.  It takes a while of walking, but when someone gets you they\\'ll almost definitely go all the way across to Bend.  I\\'ve done it going both ways with great success, you just have to not mind waiting.

When heading east to Idaho I highly recommend walking down US-20 with your thumb out.  It takes a while for some one to get you, but when they do they are highly likely to be going all the way across to Boise.  I\\'ve done this going Bend to Boise and reverse with great success.

My friend dropped me off to hitch south here, and later I used it again.  Its not great, but not bad either.  I think both times I waited about an hour, but the woods on the off ramp looked good for camping tucked away.
Flying J truck stop close by. Traffic picks up speed fast at this on-ramp, so stand at a safe place near the start, with plenty of room for drivers to pull over.
Going down Ben Higgins Rd is one way to get onto 400 South out of Dahlonega. You'll need a sign saying \"400\".

Hitchhike from truck stop exit, where truckers leave property. Cops do NOT want hitchhikers standing at on-ramps. Too dangerous there. You may have to wait 1-2 hours for a ride, but it will be long. I have hitchhiked both east and west from here. Beware of gay drivers looking for favors. Many of them use this spot to find sex.
senecA
The north shore of Oahu is surfers country - perfect for hitching!
wait here a while and you are bound to get a ride sometime and it is next to a wal-mart so you can get food and drink and supplies becarefull the cops here are a bit touchy
North on I-89: Difficult for a car to pull aside and dense traffic along Williston Rd but feasible if a car pull in the gas station court
Northward: Good spot with enough space to be hitching safely but a quite low traffic

Big parking area on the edge of town. Had a loooong walk to get out of the city though. Plenty of offers here, but all short distances. On the 101, though, my advice is take what you can get!! After a couple of hours, we settled on one that took us 2 miles :P

This spot is convenient for obvious reasons, as it's close to downtown and does not require a bus ride. There's also a shoulder. Since traffic is going several different directions, it's a good idea to hold a sign. I waited less than an hour here for a ride to Portland, which is pretty decent by American standards.
This road depends on the time of year, time of day and the weather.  Best to go during the spring and summer months.  Another road that might not take you the entire way due to local traffic.
Somehow the 101 doesn't live up to its historical hitchhiking standards.  I started hitching around 9am here and it took about 2 hours!  I guess I had no other choice but to wait :'(
Was hitchhiking any direction - north or south.  Mostly it's rush hour traffic that won't bother with a hitchhiker, so be prepared to wait a while.  My wait was about 90 minutes.

SIGN said BOISE

boring wait, lots of smiles from people.  Didn't get a long ride, but it was a ride out of town at least.

If your heading east from Bar Harbor towards Canada this is the place to wait.  Most people even going in this direction are going far - this is the more rural area of the state - and there is good visibility and a huge shoulder.

It is not totally easy to hitchhike from Manhattan. I took a bus from Port Authority Bus Terminal to Allentown (20.5 USD)
Look Allentown to  find good place to go the I78 South.

(It was said that NEW JERSEY has a stupid law that forbids HH so the Bus-ride is great to skip this state. allentown is second stop in Pennsylvania)

I HH to Harrisburg

took me some 30 minutes to get picked up since traffic is not too heavy on this onramp.

Good> cars can stop here on the broad on ramp easily

Great spot for drivers going north or south on the I-15.  You can ask them directly as they are pumping gas.  Also, there are tons of semi-trucks.  It seems that you can go as far as Los Angeles or Salt Lake quite easily from here.
really tough i had to swing a greyhound. no travelers aid
a way to get onto the I-89 north. pretty decent spot, but low and mainly local traffic
Useful non-freeway stretch of US101 just south of Petaluma.  Not perfect, but beats a suburban onramp if you're trying for a long northbound ride.

Got stuck here after dark.  Plenty of people at the Shell station offered rides, but all going southbound, we needed northbound.  In the morning got a ride from the onramp to the north side of Eugene.
worst possible place to thumb it. Lots of traffic but not one kind soul. sat her for seven hours.

People turning on 141 see you from far and have time to make a decision. Was afraid first of having no cars passing by, but there were a few stills. 

Got lucky with a ride going far up North.
Curious driver with a lot of questions, we quickly stopped in a bar to say hi to one of his friends, he got me there a bowl of delicious clam chowder soup.

Brought here by my host in Bozeman.
Okay shoulder and not a lot of people actually going through the ramp.
Had an offer for a ride to Manhattan after only a few seconds. I declined, as it was too short.

Had to wait another half hour to get a ride from Laif to Three Forks. He was on his way to give flight classes.
When he dropped me he offered to get me a sandwich and insisted on giving me a Bible.

Cops passed but didn't say anything.

Three gas stations with low traffic, easy even for one person to keep an eye on all of them and ask around. 
Maverik had the most cars, but I got asked to stop after 10-15'. The clerk offered to call the local church to see if someone could give me a ride to Pocatello.

Never heard back from this, but I end up having a ride from Valory. Full of energy, she always has a story to tell and used to pick up people!
At first, she saw me and give me a huge bag of cereals and left to bring me back a

Got kicked out of the closest Maverik gas station in less than a minute by an employee.

The on-ramp was perfect, but highway patrol pulled over after 10-15'. Apparently, they got called I was getting in front of vehicles (I was not).

They seem bothered bc they had to ask me to leave and couldn't offer me any alternative to keep going. I went on the road before the traffic light. They said nothing bc it was out of their jurisdiction. Got a ride soon after that from Verona, a retired woman h

All the room to stop, but most of the traffic wasn't going on the Interstate.

Got a ride from a man in his thirties, heading to work.

Maybell offers nothing during the winter. Only restaurant is closed and only one gas station open. Very low traffic.

Got offered a ride to Rocky Springs, WY after 5', but not my way.

Despite excellent situation on the only road going through town (great shoulder, visibility and cars slowing down), I walked out to get potential traffic coming from CO 318. Bad idea, as the time of my wait, no cars went my direction coming from this way.

Got a ride finally by a young Mormon who saw me earl

Technically good spot who allow asking at the gas station and panhandle the car passing US40 at the same time. The issue is this road leads to nothing, so not much traffic. Clerk working there is very nice, we had a good chat.

The day before, walked all the way there through main road in town and hitchhiked there an hour until sun sets. Not a lot of traffic and plenty of people giving me mean looks. 
The only car who stopped was to tell me to try to go further to increase my chances.

Next

Clear area, can be seen from far away. Plenty of space to stop, but cars were driving fast.

A latino family stopped and drove me to the  next town. Offered me coffee and the driver gave me her number in case I needed a place to stay.
Was too early for that tho

Still in pitch dark, trying to reach the Hotsprings.

And Matt stopped !

He passed me going downhill, and came back thinking that he couldn't let me there alone. 
Also offered me to host me in case I was in need.

Middle of nowhere. I started walking South towards Rollinsville and rising thumb&sign each time a car would pass me by (not a lot).

A couple who passed me going the other way came back to pick me up.
They keep driving further towards I-70. They actually were the folk/Rock-Americana band Strangebyrds. We talked about US politics, travels, art, etc. 

A very nice ride indeed !

Small town, with a good spot to hitchhike on the road and asking directly at the gas station.

Got offered a ride by someone who stopped at the gas station and saw me first with my sign. He has a hitchhiker friend so it motivates him to stop and help.
Offered to hang out in Denver while I'm around.

There's a jail few miles up north, might reduce chance of rides from local or depending on your looks.

Good traffic. I got a first car stopping after 15 minutes, but wasn't going far enough.

Finally, Joe, an old vet in a cool Cadillac staying at Buena Vista for winter.  

Great music on board and heated seats.

Friendly traffic, but didn't stop that much. Met my first panhandler of my trip n the Walmart parking lot.

Got finally a ride in a pickup bed.
Lots fun but quite cold.

Got kicked out of the close Buc-ee's.

Nice ramp with enough space.

A Georgian delivery man gave me a ride on his way to LA. Spent the ride talking with him in Russian through translator. 
He would have brought me to Las Vegas, NM, if he didn't have the work tracker on his van. 

Offered me money, water bottles snacks and an external battery, and to meet him in LA when I'll be there as well !

Dropped at the close gas station by my Dallas host. Very nice people working there, but no cars.

Went on the road, large shoulders.

Got a ride from someone who came back to pick me up, a retired man living in Decatur. 
He agreed to drive a few extra miles to drop me directly on US287 as I could continue heading to Wichita Falls.

He let me draw my next sign in his car because of how windy it was outside.
Strong rains, got a short ride from a local, trying to get closer to Dallas to find some public transportation to reach Downtown.

Had a sign saying "Athens". I ended having all the way closer to Dallas from a former hitchhiker who used to travel all over the country. 

'Dog', proudly republican and member of the band Black Ice.

Offered me money at the end of the ride, even if I told him he didn't have to.
Gave me his # as well, telling me I have a friend in Texas now, if I ever come back in the area.

Got pulled over by the police during the ride, but for silly reasons. Nothing happened.

Started asking around at gas stations at the intersection. At one of them, a man rudely asked me not to talk to women as I was asking one for a ride. "Because that's how it is in Teexas (Bullshit)

Ended up going on the road because there was a nice shoulder.
A lady (ironic, isn't it ?) stopped to as it was starting raining.
Nice ride, nothing to add.

A first car stopped and someone offered me $100 to go buy a phone for his girl. Seemed fishy and kindly rejected the offer. 

A lady ends up stopping, after she passed me first on the highway.
I was initially planning to reach Angelina State Park to spend the night, but she couldn't drive me that far, so she offered me instead to spend the night at her place and to drove me the day after to Lufkin. 
It ends up being a ride all the way to Alto with a stop, at the Sam Rayburn Dam to show me th

Mostly locals at the gas station who was quite empty, possible to hitch on the road and talking to them as well.
Got a few bucks.
An old man gave me a ride to bring me closer to Highway 90 and have only the traffic going my direction, before he went back to New Orleans.

Slow traffic and nice bystanders to talk with while waiting. 

A Californian couple end up picking me up, giving me lots of life, stock and job advices along the way. They ended dropping me further than planned to help me increase my chances to get a next ride.

Spot reached thanks to Tri-Rail from Miami area. Good shoulder. 

Driver was on his way to Tampa. After an hour of good chat, agreed to do a 1-hour detour to drop me in the city where I was supposed to spend Christmas Eve.

Got here to go through Alligator Alley. 
Little traffic, but might be due to the road works, at the time.

Might have more chance at the previous ramp (Golden Gate Parkway)

A VTC driver going back to Miami picked me up, telling me she was going through this road multiple times a day.
Got offered Fuji Water and listening to her daughter's music, an upcoming famous singer in Brazil!

Good traffic, great shoulder. 

Got a ride from an Uber driver who passed me through a first time. He accepted to drive me all the way to Naples as he was getting there to get more rides.

Nice man, open-minded with whom I had a great discussion over various subjects.

Dropped here in the morning by my host.

Foolishly refused a ride offered as I arrived on the spot because it wasn't bringing me all the way to the Interstate. (Don't do that, there are buses from Downtown Ft Myers who bring you to I75)

Waited another hour before I had a Brazilian joyful Christian who brought me all the way to the Interstate.

Employees from the nearby Love's ask me to leave, but they didn't really know if I was or not allowed to hitchhike at the gas station.

Nice amount of traffic and perfect shoulder to stop. Refused two too short rides before I accepted one from an old woman telling me the next exit has better traffic.
She said she stopped because it was "Christmas"

The Super 8 gas station nearby immediately asked me to leave. 

Fun spot, regarding the traffic lights pace, it is possible to hitchhike at the same time cars coming from East and West.

Got a ride from a very friendly former teacher, who offered me a great chat. 
Stuck after in Fort Myers where he dropped me off, he even ended up hosting me.

As the gas station clerk got out to talk to me, I got a ride to pass the bridge.

Nice man working in polish concrete, he accepted to drop me South on I-75 for me to be in the good direction for the rest of my trip.

2nd or 3rd car pulled over.
Very nice Cuban Uber driver who shared me his tricky and unbearable situation in this country while he was on his way to get a passenger.
After 30', I've been asked to leave the closest gas station. Ended up being picked up shortly after, because I "didn't look American".

Recommend on Hitchwiki.

Police passed by many times and didn't say anything.

Got a ride from a Mexican worker, very nice. He offered me an extra pair of gloves.

Was looking for a ride South to Atlanta, but only locals or people heading North.
Very friendly people, received a bit of cash, got offers to be picked up the next morning and to spend the night at a shelter center in town.

Got kicked out of the Valero on the other side of the Highway after 20' and went to this gas station under local recommendation.

After two hours, a cop showed up and told me it was illegal to panhandle in this county. (idk if he was right, but I don't think so)
finall

Asked for rides at the Shell Station. 
Talked to very nice people in majority, who gave me prayers, warm clothes, food, drinks & cash. 
The gas station employee even brought me hot food at some point.
One of them even offer to host me in his AirBNB if I couldn't find a ride.

Avoid the BP next to it, I got kicked out very fast by the manager.

My rider first gave me $20 before getting me a ride all the way to Chattanooga, TN. 
During the ride, he paid for my hotel room so I could keep go

Plenty of room to stop.

My driver came back and picked me up, because Jesus told her to do so. And because I could only be nice as I was dancing.

Gave me a bag of dates and a few singles.

Dropped here by a local CS.
He told me all his previous hitchhikers got a ride from there on I81.
Great location, but no one stopped, except a policeman.
He told me I wasn't allowed to hitchhike here, but when I said I checked the law and I was fine, he ended up acknowledging his mistake and let me keep going, only asking me to be cautious.

Tried the Shell gas station too, but almost no traffic and clerks not nice.

Got a ride from a local, thanks to a "fun" sign

At the train station, I asked bluntly to the train clerk if he would let me hitchhike the local train. He was very nice and accepted right away, although he wasn't totally allowed to do it.
Always worth to ask !
Got picked up very fast to Fort Payne. Could definitely get further if you're lucky lots of cars passing.
Not a lot of traffic but got a ride to Palm springs
Asked around for awhile got a ride to Las Cruces
Waited in the evening with no luck, camped and got a ride early morning to Jennings
Good traffic long wait short rides
Waited here 2 hours the night before and then camped , got a ride quick the next morning from the sheriff and got blessed with some Cajun food
low-key boring
Decent shoulder , good place to go east , got lucky with someone who would take us north though

Theres a corner with a stop sign where drivers can go up the northbound ramp. Good visibility. The aloha spirit will surely move a driver to lend you a ride if you wait. Someone took me to the Marine base and back.
Got dropped off here, our driver was going to the wide spread panic show, ended up hanging around and got a ride all the way to Coco Beach the next day
Asked around got a ride to the next rest area

good visibility, traffic not too slow not too fast, but the ramp is pretty short. I got picked up by someone who didn't speak english and likely wasn't local, so I don't know how likely a local is to pick you up here, I think I just got lucky.
Illegal but got dropped off here, got a ride pretty quick to clinton
Spot was somewhere around here , not much shoulder but still got a short ride to a better place down the road
Not all that much traffic but got a ride to Mars Hill where it was easy to get someone going to Ashville
Waited for a bit but eventually got a ride a few miles down to a truck stop. Got yelled at by a local though
Hard spot to go south , little to no shoulder, got lucky and a lady picked us up and drove us 20 miles south
Very shady backroads, other than that, my driver was a nice lady, probably in her mid-60s.
Not a great spot but anywhere on 84 in Eastern Oregon you have a good shot of making it across to the Portland area.

Didn't wait too long, but not a good spot in the middle of the city with no gas station nearby. Bunch of cops at the Diner on Sunday morning had me nervous but eventually a woman stopped and took me to Tremonton.
Walked on this gravel road about an hour before I caught a ride. Nice local lady who said the Lord's Prayer when I got out of the car.

After about 5 minutes a cop showed up to inform me that you can't hitchhike the on-ramps since they are technically part of the Interstate. I walked to the grass area by the road right before it peels off to the onramp and got a ride to Lincoln pretty quick. Not a bad experience but I generally found the cops to be a nuisance in Nebraska
Not a lot of traffic getting on the interstate here. Got a ride from a guy who goes to pick up his kids from their mother at the Iowa border.
Waited awhile at this junction. Couldn't figure out if going north to 88 directly would've been better than going west. Eventually caught a ride all the way to Rock Falls.
Ride from a guy in a super cool old Ford Ranchero.
Best spot in Pueblo most likely. Caught a local guy going down to Walsenburg. He told me all about his obsession with the Roswell alien conspiracy.
Not a great spot at all but people in CO are nice.
I 25 is not as happy hitching as the routes farther west in the state.
Picked up by a Navy man going home from his night shift. Offered to drop me wherever within 30 minutes

ended up here after walking i-70 for a little bit, concerned mom got us snacks and drove us what we were gonna walk. got on the onramp and waited a bit before an older man offered to take us to limon. trucker on a day off, seemed to be headed back home from an errand. truly just a day of dumb luck, onramp wasnt very busy, most people would have stopped in bennett for gas

Not sure if this is the best spot, but sure as hell got lucky! Got a lift into Moab to fix my gear and then back and into Canyonlands for a day and along to Green River after. Expensive campsite nearby and not much in the way of food but worked for me!

Not the worst spot, but a cop came and was a bit weird about whether I was allowed to hitch a ride from here (he let me eventually). Great spot to camp out behind the Love's behind a pile of old concrete and crap to stay hidden. Very dusty!
Cop took us to Mathison.
Long wait. Got picked up by a couple of rappers headed to do some DoorDash in Starkville. Large gun in the backseat.
Lot's of nice people at the gas station said they'd like to help but they had to go to work.
Quick ride up an exit from a girl that grooms dogs.
Lots of looks in Lewes. Finally thumbed a ride to Georgetown from a woman who just dropped her kids off at school.
Horrible spot but a Jamaican guy stopped pretty quick. He was on his way to deliver groceries to his grandmother.
Girl stopped in the left lane first to get a look at us, cars swerving and honking, then pulled over and took us down an exit.
NJ is very densely populated so you can expect short rides.
Not a great on ramp. We got a ride on the freeway soon enough. This is where the population density starts to really go up, so expect short rides.
Waited awhile around sunset. Eventually got a lift from a couple of Navy guys headed out to the base in Groton.
Cops pulled up and took us off the interstate.
Lots of cars on the freeway.
Long wait but finally we got picked up by a girl going to Acadia.
Slow highway. Ride from a guy who told us all about Manchester. Complained about the New York transplants but admitted that he was one himself.
Ride up to Arlington, Vermont from a girl with a guitar. She took us to the state park for some jamming and swimming.
German guy took us almost to Vermont. Talked about beer the whole way.
Felt a little odd hitchhiking in the middle of the city but we got a ride all the way to the bus station in Troy pretty quick. All the folks we met in upstate New York were really nice.
Not a bad spot. Plenty of traffic and good enough pullout. Tall grass and lots of ticks -- but that's the case about everywhere in the northeast. Got a ride to Newburgh.
Pretty quiet spot considering the truck stop. Got a ride all the way to PA from an off-duty cop.
Ok lil spot.. not a lot of pull off room but you can make it work.. try to stand by the bridge..

Tried further down to the onramp for a while before switching to this stop and got a ride pretty quick. The people at the k and r across the street are real nice and gave me plenty of ice water. It’s also a good spot to strike up a chat with diner customers and everyone getting on the I-5 gotta go through here.

Spot was good but wait was super long. Finally walked out onto the Interstate. Got a ride to Blacksburg and partied it up. The girl that picked us up had an apartment for us to crash at. Happy hitching in SW VA.
Ride up into VA from a teenager. Great shoulder
Great shoulder but very low traffic. Finally got a ride up to the Interstate from a guy who was headed to play airsoft.
Was feeling disheartened after the cops chased us off the interstate. But then we got a ride from a trucker bound for Manchester. You never know.
Caught a lift all the way to West Memphis with a few Hispanic construction workers.
Ride from a super libertarian ex-cop who dropped us a mile off our route because "Arkansas is this way".
Once the rain finally stopped, we hit the highway. Our driver was begrudging and his wife didn't acknowledge us at all. Some hard traveling in Eastern Oklahoma
I 40 thru east Oklahoma is just a slow hitch. Rides from locals all day. A couple guys who just moved from Missouri.
Not easy for cars to pull over.  Next time I might try at the gas station up the street

Carroll has a lot of people, and a delivery driver offered a ride that I said I'd take but he drove off. Got a ride after 30 right before sunset from a fellow hitchhiker, and he said it's code. Cop pulled into the parking lot right before. Many people were headed home from work or had kids in the car, definitely could be a better spot down the road for a longer duration of visibility as the cars come up.
25's. Got a short ride outside of town. Friendly ppl.
25's. Got picked up by this guy in a Camaro, but he wasn't going far. Could not refuse.
25's. Little traffic, most people look at me like "wtf bro ?". But good visibility and room to stop
25's. Location is ok, people just don't stop. Big wait but good ride
25's. I got lucky I found this spanish guy, not a lot of people were paying attention..
25's Got a small ride here.

Good spot to stop, we hitchhicked from the little traffic island in the middle of the roed, better fisibility and cars can pull over in the parking area. Super friendly people, they took us to they place for the night and then ot Lafayette !
Didn’t bank on a hitch here on a Tuesday. Walked 2 hours down the mountain from hart’s pass before getting picked up.
Usually you can wait for hikers to come down from the Trinity Alps but on a weird day (not weekend) we needed up hiking quite a ways down the road before someone came.
Long wait because we were last in line and had a group of 8 hitching north to Reno
Good location, easy to pull over, but really few people did stop, and only for small rides
end of a 500mi back pack trip out of the woods dirty as can be. Got a ride in out 90min to Silver City NM. Alma has a store but man it is out there, local traffic only.
This is best way south to STL. Do not try I-72E, locals don't take that route. also don't camp overnight if possible, many bums in this town especially along broadway
Not the best place to hitchhike but sometimes that's where you end up. Got lucky at sundown with a ride to Ritzville from a couple of local teachers. They dropped us at the park and we tucked away.

Super low traffic, might not be the best onramp to get stuck at. There was a no hitchhiking sign but the cops didn't seem to care. Got a ride from a guy going to North Bend. He was running simultaneous DoorDash and Uber orders.

Hitchhiked into sunset with no luck. Camped in the sagebrush just outside of town between the road and the railroad tracks. Took us the better part of the morning thumbing before we finally got a ride over the pass with a college professor  who gave us clementines, nut butter, and bread.
Blanca is a nice, quiet town. Cop came by and ran our IDs and then wished us luck on the adventure. Finally got a short ride to Fort Garland in the back of a pickup.
Good spot but slow hitchhiking. The sunflowers are very nice in late summer.
Short ride to Del Norte after a very long wait. This area might not be as good for hitchhiking as other areas of the state.
Not a great spot but got lucky at sunset when a couple picked us up and drove us 3 hours south to our destination. Colorado is happy hitching!
Hitchhiking south out of Jackson is a little tough. Got a ride from a local to a better spot.

Good spot but the vibes for hitchhiking in the panhandle were clearly off. Cops drove by at 10 minute intervals. The couple who picked us up was super chill, talked about art school, Ornithology, and DNA.
Very slow, early morning traffic. Got a ride from a brother and sister headed to Spokane. Big mistake going all the way to Spokane, should have asked to be dropped at the rest area before the city.
The spot was good, but there is a traffic light 400 meters before, and cars drive pretty fast there.

Going to Vegas.
Spot is honestly pretty bad.
People go fast, it's hard to stop anywhere and there's too much distraction for people to really pay attention. 
I got extremely very lucky.
Best strategy is I think to got talk to truckers at the stations
Cars have space to stop, might be too focused on traffic to notice you
Very quiet onramp, but I happened to catch a car there in almost no time!

Seemingly a good spot with heavy traffic, but no luck for me on a Thursday morning. Got a car stopping within 5 minutes, only to get told off for trying to hitchhike. Almost an hour later someone stopped but went West towards Seattle, while I wanted to go East. Gave up at that point.
Good time, but I think I'm a lucky bitch today. 65 mph its way too fast to see and understand what kind of person you are. But maybe people just really kind there idk
Almost dead zone for hitchhiking, but Appalachian trail nearby helps
Everyone think you are homeless and have some drugs in you pocket
Not a great spot, but finally got a great ride with a black guy with no windows (he wore goggles). I'm white and the music switched from Young Dolph to Drake - hopefully a coincidence!
Not a bad spot but the pigs made me drop my sign. Eventually picked up by a young Catholic priest on his way to a holiday in Florida, really nice guy and no funny business.
Picked up by an older couple who put me in the back of their pickup, great fun but not a great spot!

It isn't the best spot for pulling over, but flying right under the No pedestrian sign, there is a parking lot people can pull into. Decent amount of traffic, though id say most people passing by are not headed east. Guy that picked me up wasn't headed east but said he stopped because he has daughters and would want someone to pull over for them.

Decent spot if you're going to dunsmuir. Waited 3 hours and that was the furthest anyone who stopped was going (in that time only 5 pulled over). Not a lot of traffic at this spot anyways, so if you are trying to get further south I'd recommend taking a ride to Dunsmuir and getting on the Amtrak to Sac instead. Of the on ramps in Shasta this one is the best.
Cars drive relativity fast, and bus stop is smaller then I expected, but luckily there is a line for turning right where cars can stop.
Nothing out here besides the two gas stations. Stood by the highway on ramp and thumbed it. Ended up grabbing a ride all the way to Indy
Low traffic but eventually a local country boy took me to Vale. There is beauty in the silent remoteness out here.
Came out of Tyler and needed a ride into a main town with bus routes so I walked 2 ish miles down 904 till someone stopped

This seems like the best spot for going south out of Duluth. There are plenty of cars taking that ramp and there is space for them to pull over. I took the city bus from the north side of Duluth near Brighton Beach to about 3 blocks from here. I could imagine it taking a lot longer than 25 minutes to get a ride because in my experience, the hitchhiking between the Twin Cities and Duluth can be difficult at times.
Lord of local traffic, got lucky and got a ride with a dude willing to go out of his way. People were nice though, made 100 dollars over 4 hours
This intersection is in the middle of nowhere, but I got pretty lucky and got a ride up to Yakima. There is good visibility and room to pull off. Most of the traffic is going west and south.

Obviously, try not to get dropped off here. There is a surprising amount of traffic coming off of 21. You'll get a ride at some point.The bridge on I-90 doesn't have a walkway, so you won't be able to walk back to Vantage if you do end up getting dropped here.
Despite the presence of a truckstop this ramp is pretty slow. That said I got pretty lucky, and didn't have to wait too long.
Weird. Finally got a ride and he drove me all the way to my destination in the cascades.
30 minute wait in the middle of the day. Wide shoulder but fast traffic. I think I got lucky.

Hitching north out of DFW on US-75 is tough. This spot really isn't the greatest, but I got picked up surprisingly fast.

The issue is that there really isn't a good spot for vehicles to pull off. And well also, there is no transit in the area so it's a long walk to get to this spot.

The Costco near Parker rd. would probably be a better option. It's a substantialy shorter walk, and The truck entrance seems like it would offer a good place for vehicles to pull off.

This ramp has a few different truck stops to choose from. I hitched from the ramp here. I may have been better off to hitch off of the highway.

There is a lot of room for folks to pull off.

This area might be ok on a weekday, but when I was there, there was no traffic.

There is tons of room for vehicles to pull off, and a few restaurants near by. I was able to find wifi at the Denny's.
Good spot to go south
Not ideal southbound as its coming out of a curve... Northbound is probably easier.
Got a really good ride to Spokane after a long wait, but it's pretty desolate here.
don't go to miami
Lots of traffic going West. A lot of space for cars to pull over.
Good spot IF you are heading to I80 plenty of truckers willing to take you that way. But had a long wait(~3hours) to get a ride going down the highway.
Right after the bridge there's a small turn-out. Just make sure that you're visible from the bridge. Not a super good spot, but the best going north from Reedsport.

Cops came shortly after I started hitching. Said it was illegal to solicit a ride at any on/off ramp, and kicked me out. Maybe if you get a ride quick enough it doesn't matter, but the police are not kind to hitch hikers. The actually spot was pretty good, high traffic area and enough room to pull off. With the police presence though, I wouldn't recommend this spot.
Towns in this area are a bit small, so you can mostly rely on long-distance travelers that stop by for a break. I was lucky and didn't have to wait long, but just be patient just in case.
Hit the road at 6:00 AM on a Saturday. Nice lady picked me up and drove me to Garibaldi.
Hassled by the cops in this town, nothing better to do but drive up and down up and down all day. Had to wait nearly 30 minutes for a lift and the cops passed us 4 or 5 times.
Good traffic but not a lot of space to pull over. I only tried for about half an hour before walking south.

Had a sign for Eureka and another one saying 101N. It was a Tuesday afternoon in March but we got picked up in about 20 minutes and got a ride all the way past Eureka to Arcata! There isn't a legal area to pull over but anyone with a determination to pick you up certainly could do so safely as there are two onramp lanes.

I flew a sign near the onramp going North here for cumulatively about 5 hours one day....not one person stopped.  No good places  to pull over, and it seems like most of the people driving this road are either cranky old ladies, or parents driving their teenagers (two kinds of folks I've never gotten a ride from).

I wouldn't recommend.  Try the other 101 onramp on Santa Rosa Ave instead?

Wide on-ramp for cars or trucks to pull over. Gas station and food nearby. In the summer, many hitchhike from this area so you may see a hitchhiker's sign that was left behind. 
You can also catch a bus from San Francisco to this area before starting to hitchhike.

Very long wait, no shade and fast moving traffic. Eventually helped because a car broke down and someone came to help them. The guy ended up giving me a ride all the way to where I needed to go, which was super kind, but I think I was lucky
Better to wait in Santa Cruz where traffic is traveling slower, may have waited much longer if we did not get lucky
Spot where cars drive show, and have a spot to stop. Somehow i still had to wait hours.

Nothing worked. We were 2ppl, tried one of us asking at the Buc-ee's, without success. People were not very friendly. And my friend was sticking his thumb out at the freeway entrance without success either. We ended up taking a bus to San Antonio and hoping freight to go further west (Tucson)
Spot is nice everybody heading to the highway has to pass and there is room to stop.
this place sucked for hitchhiking, don’t go to dunnigan ca. stuck here for three days

I got dropped off here by a Sheriff's deputy that was surprisingly nice. He even bought me lunch. 

There wasn't as much traffic as I was expecting, but I was still able to get a ride in a reasonable amount of time.

Probably it was a nice spot, 12 years ago. Now there is a no stopping sign. Was there for about 2 hours and nothing but cops. I made a spot bit righter the route, there is a good on ramp so its just 15 minutes walk and worth it.
Mostly semi trucks on a weekday morning.
Didn't have to wait long .caught a trucker going as far east as I needed..

not the best place to catch a ride...lots of traffic (mostly wyoming plates)...waited 3h until a lift to the TA truck stop a bit east there were many more out of state plates (people going long distance)...people weren't so friendly here...

I waited 5 hours here, but there were some external circumstances. About half the time there was another hitchhiker there with two dogs, so it's possible somebody would've stopped earlier otherwise. And early on I declined a ride because the place seemed good and he was going too short a distance.

Seemed like a good spot to get on the I-40W. There's a big truck stop, plenty of cars, a not-too-bad on-ramp right after a traffic light, so cars are not going by too fast. But I got stuck here for a long time. Now I checked and I see there's a prison in Marion. Maybe that's why nobody stopped...
Standing in the on-ramp didn't work for me, as it's a bit hard for trucks to stop over there. After a few hours I moved to the exit of the truck stop with a sign, and that worked after 25 minutes or so.
Was at the on ramp for a long time with no luck , eventually just moved directly onto the 101 and got a ride after awhile
Got stock for a day. Little north traffic and people know it is a bad HH town.
Might be decent southbound, but very little northbound traffic here.  After about an hour finally got a ride 15 miles to beyond the end of the freeway, the best one can hope for from here.
Long long wait but when you do get a ride it will probably be a long one. Got an 18 year old guy driving a big empty mormon van. Wasn't doing anything so he drove me up to Twin Falls.

Terrible spot if  you  are  trying  to  catch the 84  to  Portland/ Seattle. I  tried  every 84  west  on ramp  in this god  forsaken  city  to  no  avail. 75% of all  cars  in  this  town  are  taking  the 15,  not  the 84.  Of the vehicles  that are,  they are  primarily  pickup  trucks  packed to the brim  with farming  gear  or  Mormon  families. I  have been stuck  in this city  for 2  days and since  my  dogs feet are bleeding I  will  likely be here  several  more. if  you are  heading  u

Waited for about 1 hour 30 minutes. Definitely not the best spot to hitch since the visibility is not great (its dark under the bridge) and there is limited space for the cars to stop. I got lucky with the ride. The driver said he drove past me and decided to turn around to pick me up

To get onto I-66W. If you take the 640 bus from Vienna metro stop it drops you close to here, and it's the only spot that makes sense. But it's pretty terrible - tiny amount of time for drivers to see you and very little space to stop. I did get a ride, but it was pure luck. Hitching just outside of Vienna metro seems like a better idea, plus you don't have to pay or wait for the bus.

Expect a LONGGG wait. A lot of travellers stop for gas at  this one gas station which seems like it is in the middle of no where. Have a look at the signs on the on ramp and sign your name with the other names dating back to the 30's. 
Four hours or more.
Waited for 2 hours and then camped for the night. Got a ride the next morning pretty quick
Long wait. Someone called the cops. Lots of traffic but no takers. Finally a guy pulled up and volunteered to take us to a Truckstop.
Not a good spot at all. Low visibility and fast traffic. But it is better than the turnpike.
Not a good spot at all. Low visibility and fast traffic. But it is better than the turnpike.
This ramp is surprisingly quiet. Most traffic in the area is going across the Dalles bridge
Got dropped in a bad place, and was kinda stuck hitchhiking here. The police showed up and told me to stop hitchhiking =(
Horrible. Plenty of time for people to see you, but little traffic and shoulder doesn't widen soon enough. Had to walk through town to the next one.
Also got stuck in here. Walked way too far out of town. Wide shoulders are far between. Finally got a ride after 3 hrs of different approaches.
Not the best place to be, lots of fences keeping you out of the woods and few cars, didn't wait forever, maybe 45 minutes

I have mixed feelings about this spot.  I was hitching late in the day for about 2 hours with no luck.  The next morning I was hitching for about a half hour when a girl pulled over headed all the way to Rapid City, SD!  This was the best ride I have ever gotten, but I got it in a really crappy place for hitchhiking.  Very few cars to begin with, and if she had been an Iowa resident she probably wouldn't have pulled over.

Waited for about 2 hours with no success.  I had to come back the next day.  In the morning I waited another 2 hours and right before I threw in the towel I got a ride to Benton Harbor, MI.  The ride was fine but I hated having to wait so long.  The girl that picked me up said that the people of Watervliet don't tend to think well of strangers and so I was lucky that I got a ride.  If you can help it I would advise not hitching here.
Found it very difficult to get a ride south on highway 1 from here
Absolutely horrible to hitch a ride here, way too much traffic
Super slow going here. Takes over a day to get a ride in most cases,

There's no space for calls pull over in either direction here. This road in general is not ideal, but the closer you get to the Kingston it widens. (I've seen people get picked up around there). In Poulsbo you'll have to get real close to 305 and even then it's only a few meters before space runs out.

Took a long while for a ride. Apparently this town is where all the state's sex offenders go, and the locals, even the church going ones, are coginzant of that. Luckily, there's not a sign here that says not to pick up hitchhikers.
Pilot truck stop
call police
Took 4 hours in sub-freezing temps WITH A DOG to get a ride north, even then it wasn't a local, it was a foreigner.

Sat here 6 hours, and while that isn't bad considering how hard it is to get out west of here, we got lucky with a ride with a crazy cat lady who told us about our mystical nnumbers that told of our life paths, which I would consider lucky.
Terrible town to hitch out of. Best have a phone to translate because if you get a ride they most certainly will be Mexican. Apparently 86 is way better.

Four massive truck stops at the four corners of this entrance and plenty of cars flowing, and yet no one stops. I got stuck here for a day and a half, until someone finally stopped and took me miles east of the city. 
Besides, my tent got blown away by a thunderstorm during the night. If the weather doesn't look good, just spend the night inside the Pilot truck stop, as the employees are friendly there. Just chill in the TV room. Weather can be pretty hazardous in Oklahoma.
Not busy at all. I just walked to the next entrance west. Much better! :)

This is not a very busy ramp to I-40 W. Only a few cars and trucks passing by on a Monday morning. It took me 4 hours and a half to get a ride. I am not sure what a better location would be to get out of Albuquerque, but just be patient if you try here.

The main road is very busy, but only very few cars actually hit the interstate. Besides, the police hassled me after 1 hour of intense thumbing. I gave up in the end. If you're trying to hitchhike out of Nashville, I recommend walking to entry 196. It's a long walk, but definitely worth it!
This entry is not busy at all. I had to give up after 2 hours and ask drivers directly in the nearby gas station. There I could get a ride 40 miles west, to a more convenient location.

This place is desert. Try your best to avoid being dropped off here, cause there are simply no cars hitting the I75 here. On the other hand, it's likely that first car passing by will stop, but still, avoid this place.
In late October, I didn't see much traffic here at all. I got a ride south eventually, but it was really sparse.
I can't remember why I didn't like the on-ramp here. Hm. Probably had a good reason? I got a ride to Salem; had him drop me off at the exit before because of all the bad rap that place gets.
Offered a ride immediately to Albany. I turned it down like a fool, hoping to get one all the way to Eureka. Ended up getting no more offers for a couple hours, then the sun went down. Hard to rate.
Tons of traffic and just enough room to pull off, but it's a little too intense. I had to wait a couple hours for a short ride.
There was a weird traffic pattern that kept people really slow going on this highway. I still had to wait like three hours. Rough town to get out of.
Not a good place to get westbound; seems to only really be local traffic, and long rides don't really get off here. Ended up walking a few exits west.
I didn't like any of the ramps here, but I got a great ride all the way to Omaha holding a sign and playing banjo under a tree by the pumps at Kum and Go.
Low traffic. Got a ride towards the outskirts after about an hour, but I wouldn't count on it a second time.
Walked a whole hell of a long way after getting dropped off by some drunk chick far short of where she said she was gonna drop me off at and off of the highway. Nobody has hearts here.
Spent a day and a half here, At the end of the day a semi driver who saw us several times picked us up after his shift and took us to Davenport,
there is a gas station, but i only stood on the onramp like a noobie. It was awful. Not many cars going and nobody wants to give you a ride
Tried to get up north to the interstate, waited for hours, bunch of scared old white people. finally walked into desert (dont recommend this) and someone was kind enough to take us to lovelock

Unfortunatelly I waited here more than 2 hours for a drive to Santa Cruz and I was not offered neither with shorter rides.
My driver eventually told me that people living in Carmel are very rich people, so that can be the reason that they don't care about hitchhikers.
The spot seems to be perfect for the direction to north. There is enough space for drivers to stop and also they can see you in advance.

Pretty sure I got lucky with a ride after 30 mins but overall it seemed like a tough exit though there's loads of traffic. Right out in the hot sun. There's a cardboard sign "missoula" waiting in the grass if you so care to use it!

You'd think there'd be a lot of rides considering how busy it is, but no. Waited 3.5 hours with "EAST!" sign before cops came. They don't want you flying signs of any sort, but luckily got ride shortly after.
People are going way too fast to pick you up. If you want to go to east, hitch up to Eau Claire and take 29.
Waited here for longer than I should have considering the amount of traffic. Got 3 ride offers in a 10 hour time span, the last one taking me east to Hayward.
Didn't try for too long...not a good stopping place and people are probably suspicious in this border town. freight train pulled up and hopped on that instead. Good spot to catch trains!

Had no luck hitching other exits wast of here in Aurora. Apparently there are a few prisons around and signs sayiing not to pick up hitchhikers. Finally got picked up by  a creepy old dude who told me about his gay experiences. Asked what kind of work I do, implying sex. got a ride out to a loves 20 miles out at least. But beware he drives around a lot looking for hitchhikers.

Got lucky and got a ride from a few kids on a booze cruise who made a sudden change of plans to take me to Worthington, MN  in exchange for gas money. They changed their mind 20 minutes from the border and dropped me off in the middle of nowhere, IA.
Rest stop just outside of Worthington had a 7 hour wait. Minnesota nice doesn't apply here.
Got lucky here and got picked up within an hour. Gonna put down bad because it's just a bad spot.

I rated it as good because there is space for a car to pull in and the police stopped to talk to me but said they had no problem at all with me hitchhiking there at the on ramp. It still will take some time however since you are still in the city ceter to find someone who trusts you.
I blogged about my journey to New Orleans [Hitchhiking Blog](http://www.hobospirit.com/hitchhiking-chicago-new-orleans)
On-Ramp to the Interstate bound south for Memphis

Got ride here from Olympia because it was said to be a better hitch. Lots of travelers and panhandlers. Could not get ride out South. There's a busy Pilot a few exits down and a road that you can walk down that follows the Highway that way.

May be panhandlers along highway here. Waited maybe 20 minutes with "EAST!" sign. Got picked up by cool dude who gave me dab hits and drove me to Coeur d'Alene.
I have been told though it's hard to get out of Spokane
Sat here 4 hours with sign that said "WEST" on super busy exit. Eventually got ride to Laurel, just down I-90 a bit
Good for lifts to New Jersey

For I-95 N.  
Might work, but cars are going pretty fast.
Pretty bad place to hitchhike. Very few people passing by there. We nevertheless entered on the highway, walked for 5 minutes and hitchhiked, and were taken less than 5 minutes after that.
Walked for 9 MILES with thumb out facing cars frequently. No pick ups and some dirty looks. But I did end up getting a ride from the nicest woman I met on my trip.

brutal. i had to walk through the entire city to get a ride and i felt lucky at the end. wasilla has a reputation, its not great. consider waiting for a ride to palmer if you are heading south or to  any town north of wasilla. try not to get stuck here !
waited for 3 days here. best to stop at the gas station heading out of town and ask people filling up. don't look too sketchy, since the border is nearby.

There's a truck stop. I wanted to go north-east to D.C. (Nov '14) All truck drivers seemed to go south. But there were many of them. You can try on the Interstate entry as well (got chased away but State Police and Sheriff  though). Good luck!
Wat?

you people dont know very much about hitchhiking in the usa i saw your wiki i was a professional nomad for 3 years from 2000-2003 and could tell you how to do it better then anyone 9079732022 and you know the location...
I was kicked out of here in Jan, 2014
TA truck stop at exit 7
In September had to wait 3 hours for a ride from Silver Lake to McCarthy. 4 cars passed meanwhile.
You can easily hitch anywhere on McCarthy road. In September after the tourist season dies out, the traffic gets really scarce.
Seems to be a good place to hitch - huge number of cars passing by straight to I-80, but people don't want to stop.

Good place to hitch. heavy traffic. Easy to access. most of the cars will go to west. You can ride on I-80 from this place.

You should be careful to police.
stayed on that ramp for about 5 hours till it got dark...went to a gas station up the main road and chilled there for about 4 hours till i found a ride around midnight haha

This on-ramp seems like a good spot, but it's near senseless to try, I wound up here for one and a half days before someone showed up. On plus though, this place has been used since the seventies, and the lamp pole there has an incredible amount of hitcher tags dating from the 70's to the present day
Not much space for cars to pull over, but still managed to hitch a ride south.

Waited all day here, asked around the truck stop to see if they were heading west and if they could give me a lift. Got a lot of cold shoulders. It's against most truckers work policies to pick up hitchhikers so I was told too many times. Ended up getting the bus west to Wendover where it took 10 mins of waiting on an on-ramp to hitch a ride from a trucker to Reno.

Really quite a bad place to hitchhike, not much room for cars to pull over, drivers vision of people on the side of the road is limited, not dangerous but it's unlikely you'll get a lift here. However it's possible. Waited 30 mins and got a ride to Salt Lake city.
As you would expect people leaving here are most likely only going as far as the St George center. Took 30 mins to get a lift to another on-ramp further north.
Pretty bad place to hitchhike north. Took 2 hours.
This is a bad place to hitchhike as very few people use this on-ramp. Still it only took two hours to get a ride.
Not good for heading west, nowhere for traffic to stop and a not many people passing by. Walk about a mile west for a better on ramp.
Seems like a good spot but very little traffic. Waited for two hours

Way bad spot to be in. I was stuck here for 3 hours. I suppose there's a lot worse places to be. But If it wasn't for a lucky ride I might've been stuck there a a lot longer. There's a car maybe every 10 minutes. Try to skip this place.
yea i got stuck in lake city for two days. The cops there are really bad. The entire panhandle is hard to get rides in.

Lots of panhandlers and old grizzly dudes around here, so the folks don't take too kindly to roadside peoples.  Also got hassled by the cops, but it started raining, all the other dudes went into hiding and I got a ride shortly thereafter.

Same as adjacent spot, this isn't the best place to hitch.  You CAN get really lucky if it's in the morning, but the later it is, the more difficult.  Plus, there really isn't any place for cars to stop (besides the stop sign).
Waited about an hour with heavy traffic, mainly commuters, friendly people, nice view of Ranier

seemes like a reasonable place with a light but might be way out into the middle of nowhere and people are too wary (general SC tendency?). A few trucks stop for gas. There's a shorter route sometimes taken by locals.
there's a light after a big bridge but otherwise speed is quite high, no shoulder either. Visibility is pretty good though.
Most people on the road here are locals, not traveling more than a few miles

Maybe it was just the time of day/year, but it took us awhile to get out of here. On the plus side, under the bridge makes for a great campspot if you get stuck out here. Also, don't take a ride to the elephant seals unless you can get back, there's nothing for miles north of here.

I stood here for a couple hours waiting for a ride with no luck, most likely because there is no spot to pull over, people are going fast, and if you stand there late in the day everyone driving by has the sun in their eyes and can't see you.  crappy spot.
Got a ride after 30 minutes (?).
I had to wait here by the exit of the rest area for four hours, the whole morning, picked up by a nice truck driver, one in a million.

The Flying J staff is friendly. The truckers are friendly but I found no north bounds like I had wanted. Found a craigslist rideshare to Chicago at the end of the day. Expect long waits but friendly people.
There is a flying j here. lots of traffic going all directions but expect a long wait.
US 287, got caught in a tornado warning here. Soaked through to my underpants. Hardest I've hitched in Montana.
Mostly local traffic, although I got a ride from a local going into Rapid City. Waited about an hour and a half.

If you get stuck here, there is a gas station and truck stop on the South side of the Interstate that hosts a lot of tractor trailers. I would consider asking trucks for rides- I had luck with that. Otherwise expect a VERY long wait! There is a campground if you need to stay the night across the street from the truck stop.
Bad spot. Waited awhile and accidentally (stopped to close the trunk) got a ride from a couple to the longhouse about 5 miles east much better place to hitch.
I tried 3 different exits and all angles around I-430 on the west side of Little Rock.  Rather affluent area, took me six hours to get a ride, but finally did get out of the city.

We waited a long time, but we did see another guy get picked up before us, and at the end of our wait, two cars stopped at once. Our ride took us to Olympia, and from there, you're pretty much set to be able to get to Seattle.

There's a nice pullout, with traffic going on having to stop at a light. Decent by those standards, but we got a lot of nasty looks. I'm not sure how many people around here are in to picking up hitchhikers.
Southbound. Low traffic, no ride offer over the course of an hour. Also, there's several resident spangers at this intersection, so cars may be reluctant to stop. Good luck.

Southbound. This seemed like an ideal spot; lots of traffic, wide ramp, stoplight. My experience here was pretty terrible. I had a few offers of rides two to three miles down the road and nothing else for nearly five hours. I finally left when a cop threatened me, even though I was standing in a legal spot. If heading to the bay, I'd suggest taking the bus over to I-5.
Southbound. Seemed like almost entirely local traffic. In my opinion, not worth the effort.

this is a terrible place to get a ride, i tried for about 3 hours.  If you get dropped off here, it is better to just take some of the regional transit.  It should take you as far south as Santa Maria, not sure where it goes north bound, but it is not too expensive

Lots of trucks here, but no rides, stood here for several hours before giving up.  All of the exits between here south to Corona were not productive.  I finally gave up and walked all the way to the last exit in corona, camped out, and got a ride the next morning.

I had a tough time hitching in Florida.  No shoulders, or not wide enough, and people are too rich and materialistic there, they won't even hardly look at the "bum" on the side of the road.  I eventually got a few short rides over to Crestview where I then got a good long ride, but at the very least, the panhandle sucks.
Going north. I got dropped off here and found it to be rather poor for finding a ride. Lots of yuppies and blue hairs that will be afraid of you.
The onramp near this truckstop is basically unhitchable; I managed to catch a ride to Colorado Springs after about an hour, though, after asking around at the truckstop.

This truckstop sucks. I was here asking for rides for over five hours with no luck. It didn't help that there were half a dozen tweekers bumming around who scared the drivers and tried to make off with my backpack. I'm sure it's possibile to hitch from here, but I'm not going to try again.
Flew a sign ("EAST") here for about an hour until a cop told me I couldn't, but he did give me a ride to the next rest area.

got dropped at some rest area. one without services. was going through columbus. had to ask people not thumb the ramp. very little traffic but thats cause i was on some beat rest stop.
got out though.

70 is a toll road through here. good amount of traffic. no truck stops. little town of BK's and gas stations.
ramp most likely wont work. i waited 1.4 hrs. mostly local traffic. 40 is the alternate to hook back up with 70. enjoy lawrence, its a beautiful town in summer. its an easy walk to 40 from here.
gettin out on 40 is just as bad though.
great town, bad spot.
very little traffic. if a car does come they will more than likely pick you up. stay positive.
the junction looks like a good spot but thats it. most cars which pass are tourists.

Got dropped off here.  I wouldn't suggest staying at all.  There's a nearby McDonald's with free Wifi if need be.  Walk or hitch (the road south of McDo) to the next on ramp, 3,2 miles northish.  That other on ramp feeds the freeway with more traffic and there is more space on the on ramp for cars and trucks to stop
